OAH 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC E015/PA- 24-198 
 
 
STATE OF MINNESOTA 
OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  ORDER  ON MOTION  
This matter  is pending before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie.  
On February 14, 2025, the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners (CPP- GIP) filed a motion alleging that Citizens Utility Board (CUB) 
expert witness Scott Hempling  breached the Court’s Highly Confidential Protective Order . 
CPP- GIP requests that the Court revoke Hempling’s access to Highly Confidential Trade 
Secret (HCTS) Information and strike the specific portions of Hempling’s testimony that 
include HCTS Information.  
On February 25, 2025, CUB responded to the motion.  CUB does not contest that 
Hempling breached the Highly Confidential Protective Order and does not oppose the motion.  CUB has terminated its relationship with Hempling, has withdrawn his testimony, 
and does not intend to offer his testimony into the evidentiary record. CUB ’s motion 
described its good faith response to the breach and there is no evidence CUB or its 
attorneys directed or participated in the breach by Hempling.
1  
On February 20, 2025, Hempling contacted the Office of Administrative Hearings 
and requested permission to file a letter explaining his actions.  Hempling was given leave 
to file the letter, and the parties were given the opportunity to respond.2 Hempling filed a 
letter on March 3, 2025. CPP -GIP responded on March 7, 2025.  
Based upon the record and the parties’ s ubmissions ,  
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED:  
1. Scott Hempling’s access to confidential information, including HCTS  
information,  in this matter is terminated.  Hempling shall not receive any further 
confidential  information and must either return any  information already received to CUB 
 
1 There is a good-faith dispute about whether Hempling’s original publicly -filed testimony was properly 
redacted.  As the parties agreed to resolve this dispute and Hempling’s public testimony was re-filed with 
additional redactions, the Court will not address that issue in this Order.  
2 See March 3, 2025 Order Allowing Letter.  
[217224/1 ] 2 
 
or destroy the information within five days of receiving this order. CUB shall provide this 
order to Hempling as soon as practicable.   
2. Hempling’s prefiled testimony is deemed withdrawn .  
3. CPP- GIP’s request to have Hempling’s testimony removed f rom eDockets  
is DENIED.  
 
 
Dated: March 12, 2025  
 
 
MEGAN J. McKENZIE  
Administrative  Law Judge  
 
 
 
 
 
 
March 1 2, 2025  
 
See Attached Service List   
 
Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  
 
OAH 25-2500- 40339  
MPUC E015/PA -24-198 
 
To All Persons on the Attached Service List:  
  Enclosed and served upon you is the Administrative Law Judge’s ORDER ON 
MOTION  in the above- entitled matter . 
 
If you have any questions, please contact me at (651) 361 -7970, 
cara.hunter @state.mn.us , or via facsimile at (651) 539- 0310.  
       Sincerely,  
  
 
      CARA HUNTER  
      Legal Assistant  
 
 
Enclosure  
cc: Docket Coordinator

On Behalf Of: Canada Pension Plan Investment Board, Global Infrastructure Management, LLC and ALLETE, Inc., dba Minnesota Power
content:
March 12, 2025  
 
Via e -Filing  
 
The Honorable Megan J. McKenzie  
Administrative Law Judge  
Office of Administrative Hearings  
600 North Robert Street  
St. Paul, MN  55164 -0620 
 
Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198 
 
 Highly Confidential / Highly Trade Secret Documents Relating to the Property Acquisition of 
Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and 
Global Infrastructure Partners Docket PA -24-198 
 MPUC Docket No. E -015/M -24-383 
  
Dear Judge McKenzie : 
This letter is filed on behalf of Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and 
Global Infrastructure Manage ment, LLC (“GIP” and collectively, “the Partners”) and ALLETE, Inc. 
d/b/a Minnesota Power (“the Company”) to confirm that Annie Levenson -Falk from the Citizens 
Utility Board (“CUB”) should be provided access to Highly Confidential Trade Secret materials in this 
matter.  
 
On December 19, 2024, CUB filed Trade Secret and Highly Confidential Trade Secret Non -Disclosure 
Agreements for Annie Levenson -Falk. On December 20, 2024, however, CUB filed a letter explaining 
that they intended to request HCTS access only for Brian Edstrom and Scott Hempling.  
 
Recently , CUB requested that the Partners  and the Company  permit HCTS access to Annie 
Levenson -Falk in light of the withdrawal of HCTS access for Scott Hempling . The Partners and the 
Company have agreed to do so, in recognition of and reliance on the Highly Confidential Trade 
Secret Non -Disclosure Agreement that Annie Levenson -Falk signed and filed, dated December 19, 
2024.   
 
Sincerely,  
 
 
Ryan P. Barlow  
Moss and Barnett, P.A.  
P: (612) 877 -5268 
Ryan.Barlow@lawmoss.com  
Counsel for CPP Investments and GIP  
  
 
 
 
Kodi J. Verhalen  
Kodi Verhalen  
Taft Stettinius & Hollister LLP  
P: (612) 977 -8591 
kverhalen@taftlaw.com  
Counsel for ALLETE d/b/a Minnesota Power  
 
cc: Parties of Record  
 

CERTIFICATE  OF SERVICE  
 
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners

Documents Relating to the Property 
Acquisition of Minnesota Power for

Infrastructure Partners Docket PA -24-198 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No.  E-015/PA -24-198 
 
 
 
MPUC Docket No. E -015/M -24-383 
 
 
 
 
 
Karen E. Berg  certifies that on the  12th day of  March , 2025 , she filed a true and correct 
copy of  a letter to the Honorable Megan McKenzie on behalf of the Ca nada Pension 
Plan Investment Board , Global Infrastructure Management, LLC and ALLETE, Inc., 
d/b/a Minnesota Power by positing it on www.edockets.state.mn.us .  Said document 
was also served via U.S. Mail and e -mail as designated on the Official Service List s on 
file with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission.  
 
 
 
 
/s/ Karen E. Berg   
Karen E. Berg

[217502/1 ]  
 
 OAH 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC E015/PA- 24-198 
 
 
STATE OF MINNESOTA 
OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  ORDER  RESCHEDULING PUBLIC 
HEARING  
This matter  is pending before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie.  
Based upon the record, the prehearing conference, and the parties’ stipulations,  
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED:  
1. The virtual public hearing previously scheduled  for April 9, 2025 is 
rescheduled to April 10, 2025 from 6:00-8:00 p.m.   The hearing will be conducted via 
WebEx.  
  
2. The parties must file an affidavit of publication or other evidence of proper 
notice of the public hearing no later than March 24, 2025.  
 
3. All other public hearings will take place as previously scheduled.  
 
4. Public hearings will adjourn with the last speaker, even if it is prior to the 
stated hearing end time. Therefore, members of the public who wish to speak should arrive at the beginning of the public hearing and put their names on the sign- up sheet. To 
the extent practicable, the public hearings will end at the stated end time, but may be 
extended, depending on the number of individuals wishing to provide comment.  
 Dated: March 12, 2025  
 
 
MEGAN J. McKENZIE  
Administrative  Law Judge  
 
 
 
 
March 12, 2025  
 
See Attached Service List   
 
Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  
 
OAH 25-2500- 40339  
MPUC E015/PA -24-198 
 
To All Persons on the Attached Service List:  
  Enclosed and served upon you is the Administrative Law Judge’s ORDER 
RESCHEDULING PUBLIC HEARING  in the above- entitled matter . 
 
If you have any questions, please contact me at (651) 361 -7970, 
cara.hunter @state.mn.us , or via facsimile at (651) 539- 0310.  
       Sincerely,  
  
 
      CARA HUNTER  
      Legal Assistant

OAH 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC E -015/PA -24-198  
 
 
 
STATE OF MINNESOTA 
OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
 
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
  
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners  ORDER  FOR IN CAMERA INSPECTION  
  
This matter  is pending before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie.  
On February 13, 2025, the  Minnesota  Department of Commerce (DOC) filed a 
Motion to Compel Discovery and lift HCTS Designations.
1 DOC alleges that the Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global  Infrastructure Partners (CPP -GIP) have 
improperly redacted Investment Committee Memos (IC Memos)  and have improperly 
marked a document ( SLV- D-6)2 as containing highly confidential trade secret (HCTS) 
information.  The Large Power Intervenors (LPI) filed a response supporting DOC’s motion 
on February 27, 2025.3 CPP- GIP opposed the motion on February 28 , 2025, arguing that 
redactions and HCTS designation are proper.4   
 
The Administrative Law Judge has concluded that in camera inspection of the 
documents at issue in the Motion is appropriate in connection with consideration of the pending Motion.  
 Based on all of the files and proceedings herein, the Administrative Law Judge 
make s the following:  
 
  
 
1 See 20252-215370-01  
2 This document is also know as “ DOC IR SUPP 0011.01 Attach” and is attached to the unredacted direct 
testimony of Stephanie Vavro, 20252-214942-02.  
3 20252-215830-02 
 
4 20252-215940-01 
 
[217607/1]  2 
 
ORDER  
 
1. CPP- GIP must submit unredacted copies of the disputed IC Memos for in 
camera review . The documents must be provided to the Judge via direct email as soon 
as possible but no later than noon on March 14, 2025 . 
 
2. The documents and other records provided to the Judge for review will not 
become part of the case record as a result of the submission for review. The documents and other records will be returned to CPP- GIP or destroyed following a final order on 
DOC’s motion . This does not preclude a possible order for CPP -GIP to disclose any 
reviewed documents.  
  
3. The documents and other records for review must be clearly marked or 
packaged as “ For Judge Review Only, OAH 25- 2500- 40339. ” Any markings must not 
obscure the content of the documents or other records.

On Behalf Of: Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners
content:
1 5 0  S o u t h  F i f t h  S t r e e t   |   S u i t e  1 2 0 0   |   M i n n e a p o l i s ,  M N  5 5 4 0 2  
 P : 6 1 2 -8 7 7 -5 0 0 0   F : 6 1 2 -8 7 7 -5 9 9 9   W : L a w M o s s . c o m  
  
 
March 7 , 2025 
 
Via e -Filing  
 
The Honorable Megan J. McKenzie  
Administrative Law Judge  
Office of Administrative Hearings  
600 North Robert Street  
St. Paul, MN  55164 -0620 
 
 
Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198 
 
 Highly Confidential / Highly Trade Secret Documents Relating to the Property Acquisition 
of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners Docket PA -24-198 
 MPUC Docket No. E -015/M -24-383 
  
 
Dear Judge McKenzie : 
On March 3, 2025, Your Honor issued an Order permitting Scott Hempling  (“Hempling”)  to file a 
letter by March 5, 2025, and permitting other parties to file a response to Hempling’s letter by 
March 7, 2025. Th is letter constitutes the  response of Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
(“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Manage, LLC (“GIP” and collectively, “the 
Partners”) . 
 
On February 14, 2025, the Partners filed a Motion to Revoke Access and Strike Direct Testimony 
of Scott Hempling (“Motion”) because Hempling disclosed the Partners’ Highly Confidential 
Trade Secret Information (“HCTS Information”) in violation of the protective orders issued in 
this case. The Partners requested an Order revoking Hempling’s access to HCTS Information 
and striking the portions of his Direct Testimony including HCTS Information. On February 25, 
2025, Citizens Utility Board (“CUB”) filed a response to the Motion confirming that CUB does not 
oppose the Motion, ha s terminated its relationship with Hempling, and does not intend to offer 
Hempling’s Direct Testimony into the record.  
 
In light of these developments, the Partners clarify their request for relief. Because Hempling 
will not be a witness in this case  and is therefore not eligible to access protected data , the 
Partners request an Order revoking Hempling’s  access to all protected data including HCTS 
Information  and requiring Hempling to destroy or return all protected data to the Partners . 
 
 
 
 Further, because CUB has confirmed that it will not offer Hempling’s Direct Testimony in this 
proceeding , which  as a result is “considered withdrawn” pursuant to paragraph 23 of Your 
Honor’s First Prehearing Order , the Partners request an Order that all versions of Hempling’s 
Direct Testimony  (but not the Motion, Response to Motion of CUB, or Hempling’s letter)  be 
withdrawn from the eFiling system.  
 
The Partners do not , at this time,  request any sanctions against Hempling  from Your Honor , but 
the Partners retain their rights to seek any and all  legal and equitable remedies regarding the 
release of not public data and violation of the protective orders.  
 
Sincerely,  
 
Ryan P. Barlow  
Attorney at Law  
P: (612) 877 -5268 
Ryan.Barlow@lawmoss.com  
 
RPB 
 
cc: Parties of Record  
 
CERTIFICATE  OF SERVICE  
 
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 
Highly Confidential / Highly Trade Secret 
Documents Relating to the Property 
Acquisition of Minnesota Power for 
Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension 
Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners Docket PA -24-198 OAH Docket No. 25-2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No.  E-015/PA -24-198 
 
 
 
MPUC Docket No. E -015/M -24-383 
 
 
 
 
 
Katherine J. Marshall  certifies that on the  7th day of  March , 2025 , she filed a true and 
correct copy of  the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure 
Partners’ response to Scott Hempling ’s letter by positing it on 
www.edockets.state.mn.us .  Said document was also served via U.S. Mail and e -mail 
as designated on the Official Service List s on file with the Minnesota Public Utilities 
Commission.  
 
 
 
 
/s/ Katherine J. Marshall   
Katherine  J. Marshall

Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS 1 
Q. Please state your name , employer, and position . 2 
A. My name is Jennifer J. Cady, I am employed by ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power1 3 
as Vice President of Regulatory and Legislative Affairs.   4 
 5 
Q. Did you provide Direct Testimony in this proceeding?  6 
A. Yes. 7 
 8 
Q. Please  summarize your Direct Testimony in this proceeding . 9 
A. My Direct Testimony discussed the underlying policy reasons for the proposed 10 
Acquisition of all outstanding shares of ALLETE by the Canada Pension Plan 11 
Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) 12 
(together, the “Partners”) and why the  proposed acquisition of ALLETE  (“Acquisition ”) 13 
is in the public interest. Minnesota Power  is one of the most unique utilities in the nation 14 
due to the majority of its energy sales supporting energy intensive industrial customers  15 
in mining and paper production . As  Minnesota Power has provided near-perfect 16 
reliability to customers , the Company  has also been a leader in the State of Minnesota 17 
in both energy conservation and in decarbonizing its electric generation fleet and 18 
transitioning to renewable energy . This is  evidenced by its ability  both to provide the 19 
most renewable energy to customers of any utility and the lowest total residential 20 
customer bills in Minnesota  today.  21 
 22 
The Company has a unique connection to the customers and communities it serves . The 23 
Company also  values its employees as central to all we do each day . ALLETE  24 
intentionally chose partners who share these values and are aligned with its long-term 25 
strategy. This intentional partnership with established long -term infrastructure 26 
investors , the Partners , will allow Minnesota Power to access capital for the investments 27 
 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Rebuttal  Testimony and the 
Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically 
defined, references to “ALLETE” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota 
Power and all re gulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
 
 2 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  needed in the clean energy transition, while removing this relatively small energy 1 
company with outsized risk due to its unique customer mix from the volatile public 2 
markets , which are driven by quarter -to-quarter financial results  today . Additionally, 3 
this Acquisition does nothing to change the oversight that the Minnesota Public Utilities 4 
Commission (“ Commission ”) has over Minnesota Power’s operations, rates, resource 5 
planning , or resource acquisitions. The Company’s obligations and intent to comply 6 
with Minnesota’s energy policy and Commission directives are unchanged by this 7 
Acquisition and are, in fact, supported by this Acquisition.  8 
 9 
Q. What is the purpose of your testimony?  10 
A. I am providing Rebuttal Testimony in response to testimony provided from Department  11 
of Commerce (“Department”) Witnesses Stephanie Vavro and Craig M. Addonizio, 12 
Large Power Intervenor s (“LPI”) Witness  Christopher C. Walters, CURE Witness Jim 13 
Baker , and Sierra Club Witness Courtney Lane.  14 
 15 
Q. Is there any other witness testimony you address in your Rebuttal Testimony?  16 
A.  No. Based on  Citizen s Utility Board  of Minnesota ’s (“CUB ”) Response to the Motion 17 
to Strike and Revoke Access,  dated  February 25, 2025, I understand that  CUB has 18 
withdrawn Scott Hempling’s pre -filed Direct Testimony and no longer plans to file 19 
further testimony from him.  Because CUB has withdrawn that testimony, Minnesota 20 
Power and the Partners do not address it  in rebuttal and instead focus on other witnesses’ 21 
testimony.   22 
 23 
Q. How is your testimony organized?  24 
A. My Rebuttal Testimony first provides an introduction, an update on other regulatory 25 
proceedings, an overview of Party  Direct Testimony (“ Party  Testimony”) , an overview 26 
of the regulatory compact  and public interest standard, Minnesota Power’s view on 27 
energy policy as it relate s to this Acquisition, a response to Party  Testimony  regarding 28 
customer rates and affordability, and a brief discussion of transparency and affiliated 29 
interest concerns.   30 
 31 
 
 3 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  I also address the risks to the Company and our customers if this Acquisition is not 1 
approved. My Rebuttal Testimony, along with the Rebuttal Testimony of Witness 2 
Scissons, explains that rejection of the Acquisition would create significant risks for 3 
Minnesota Power and our customers, including risks in our ability to meet Minnesota  4 
policy requirements and the loss of particular benefits of acquisition by the Partners. 5 
Other parties do not recognize these very real risks, which limits the value of their 6 
analysis and recommendations.  7 
 8 
 Finally, my Rebuttal Testimony summarizes  the previous commitments made by the 9 
Company and the Partners in the Merger Agreement and the July 19, 2024 Petition, 10 
along with a number of significant new commitments made by Minnesota Power and 11 
the Partners  in Rebuttal Testimony  to address concerns communicated in Party  12 
Testimony. These commitments include tangible benefits to both Minnesota Power 13 
employees and customers, as well as financial commitments from the Partners to the 14 
Company, and commitments intended to address concerns around transparency and 15 
affiliated interest issues.  16 
 17

A. Yes. I am sponsoring the following schedules to my Rebuttal Testimony:  19

II. UPDATE ON OTHER REGULATED UTILITY PROCEEDINGS 23 
Q. What other re gulatory  approvals are necessary for the Acquisition?  24 
A. The Acquisition needs to receive approvals from the Federal Energy Regulatory 25 
Commission (“FERC”) and the Public Service Commission of Wis consin (“PSCW”).  26 
 27 
Q. Did the Commission request any information regarding these agency reviews?  28 
A. Yes. Order Point 3(E) of the Commission’s referral Order requested the following: 29 
“How do relevant and related dockets pending before the [FERC], [PSCW], and/or other 30

MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  state, federal or foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration 1 
of the [Acquisition] ?”2 2 
 3 
Q. Since your Direct Testimony was filed on December 12, 2024, have there been 4 
developments in any of the other proceedings noted above?  5 
A. Yes. On December 19, 2024,  the FERC issued an Order  in Docket No. EC24 -105-000 6 
approving the Acquisition . The Order states, “As discussed below, we author ize the 7 
Proposed Transaction as consistent with the public interest.”3  8 
 9 
 Additionally, on January 23, 2025,  all parties to the PSCW’s proceeding on this matter 10 
agreed to waive their respective rights to a contested case hearing and executed a 11 
Stipulation of Facts and Waiver of Hearing  (“Stipulation”) . The Stipulation was agreed 12 
to by all parties, including the Citizens Utility Board of Wisconsin, the International 13 
Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (“IBEW”)  Local 31, Madison Gas and Electric 14 
Company, Wisconsin Electric Power Company , and the Wisconsin Public Service 15 
Corporation. On February 11, 2025,  PSCW Staff issued a Memorandum  for comment  16 
concerning Superior Water Light and Power’s petition for a declaratory ruling  or, in the 17 
alternative, request for all required approvals under the Wisconsin Utility Holding 18 
Company Act (“WUHCA”) . On February 25, 2024 , Superior Water Light and Power 19 
and the Partners , as joint applicants , filed comments  on the Staff Memorandum  in 20 
support of the petition . Madison Gas and Electric Company  and Wisconsin Electric 21 
Power Company  filed joint comments  indicating that they do not oppose the 22 
Acquisition. No other parties filed comments.  A virtual public hearing is scheduled in 23 
this matter for March 4, 2025. Following the public hearing , the matter will await a final 24 
decision from  the PSCW.  25 
 26

III. OVERVIEW OF PARTY TESTIMONY 4 
Q. What parties filed Party  Testimony in this proceeding ? 5 
A. The following parties filed testimony on February 5, 2025 in this case: the Department, 6 
Office of the Attorney General (“OAG”), LPI, CUB, Laborers’ International Union of 7 
North America ( “LIUNA”), IBEW Local 31 , the Sierra Club , and CURE  (collectively 8 
the “Parties”) .  9 
 10 
Q. What were the key themes raised in Party  Testimony ? 11 
A. The Parties  above  filed substantive testimony  on the proposed Acquisition . Across the 12 
testimony the Company identified  several key themes that were addressed by multiple 13 
witnesses, including: the Partners’ financial commitments to Minnesota Power, issues 14 
related to capital structure of the utility (equity and debt), corporate separateness/ring - 15 
fencing, governance, affiliated interests, books and records, ratemaking and 16 
affordability, workforce and labor protections, core values of Minnesota Power, and 17 
environmental and energy policy concerns. Concerningly, some parties also expressed 18 
concerns about the foundational need for the Acquisition.  19 
 20 
Q. What is the Company ’s overarching response to filed testimony ?  21 
A. As the Company explained in its Petition and in its Direct Testimony, it has carefully 22 
analyzed what it needs to do in order to continue to provide safe, reliable, and affordable 23 
service and satisfy Minnesota’s policy requirements in the future. In short, it will require 24 
investments that are significantly increased compared to ALLETE’s  historical level of 25 
investments. After a thorough review, including the best information and the advice of 26 
independent financial consultants, the ALLETE Board determined that it would  be 27 
incredibly challenging  to meet the needs of  Minnesota Power’s  customers while relying 28 
on public markets. The Company carefully evaluated its options following that decision, 29 
and determined that acquisition by the Partners is the best path  forward . 30 
  31 
 
 6 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  While we recognize that there may be disagreements about the change being proposed, 1 
we are very concerned that Parties do not seem to recognize the significant need for that 2 
which the Acquisition is intended to resolve. It does not appear that the other Parties 3 
respect the care that the Company put into reaching this conclusion, or the risks to the 4 
Company and its customers if  required to continue to rely on public markets  for the 5 
capital needed to operate the utility . The Rebuttal Testimony provided by the Company 6 
and the Partners will address these concerns.  7 
 8 
As described in the July 19, 2024,  Petition and in Direct Testimony, both the Company 9 
and the Partners are aligned with Minnesota Power’s continued focus on customers, 10 
community , and the climate ; are confident this Acquisitio n has many positive attributes ; 11 
and testify that the Acquisition  is consistent with the public interest . That said, both the 12 
Company and the Partners seek to find consensus with interested stakeholders as much 13 
as possible and want to address the concerns raised in Party Testimony .  14 
 15

A. Specific concerns raised in Party  Testimony  will be addressed by the Rebuttal 17 
Testimony of both Company and Partner Witnesses.  18 
 19

individuals are providing Rebuttal Testimony on behalf of Minnesota Power  and the 22

IV. OVERVIEW OF THE REGULATORY COMPACT THAT REMAINS 12 
UNCHANGED BY THE ACQUISITION 13 
Q. What is the public interest standard in Minnesota?  14 
A. Minn. Stat. § 216B.01 states :  15 
It is hereby declared to be in the public interest that public utilities be 16 
regulated as hereinafter provided in order to provide the retail customers 17 
of natural gas and electric service in this state with adequate and reliable 18 
services at reasonable rates, consistent with the financial and economic 19 
requirements of public utilities and their need to construct facilities to 20 
provide such services or to otherwise obtain energy supplies, to avoid 21 
unnecessary duplication of facilities which increase the cost of service to 22 
the consumer and to minimize disputes between public utilities which 23 
may result in inconvenience or diminish efficiency in service to the 24 
consumers.  25 
 26 
Q. Describe the goals of utility regulation.  27 
A. As Department Witness Nancy Campbell testified in Minnesota Power’s last rate case :4  28 
One of the primary goals of utility regulation is to mimic  the outcome that 29 
would be achieved if a competitive market existed. To achieve this goal, 30 
regulation should provide the utility with  a reasonable opportunity to 31 
recover its cost of service, including a reasonable return on its 32 
investments. A reasonable opportunity, however, is not a guarantee. Like 33 
a firm in a competitive market, the  utility must navigate  the broader 34 
 
4 In the Matter of the Application by Minnesota Power for Authority to Increase Electric Service Rates in the State 
of Minnesota , Docket  No. E-015/GR -23-155, Nancy Campbell Direct Testimony at 4 -5 (March 18, 2024).   
 
 8 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  economy and be a good steward of its resources to make a profit. The 1 
other primary goal of utility regulation is to ensure the utility provides all 2 
of its customers with safe, reliable and affordable service.  3 
 4 
Q. What is the authority of the Commission?  5 
A. The authority of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission is outlined in Minn. Stat. 6 
§ 216B.09, which states “The commission, on its own motion or upon complaint and 7 
after reasonable notice and hearing, may ascertain and fix just and reasonable standards, 8 
classifications, rules or practices to be observed and followed by any or all public 9 
utilities with respect to the service to be furnished.”  The Commission has the authority 10 
to set rates and regulate service quality for a public utility .  11 
 12 
Q. Does the Acquisition  change the ability of the Commission to regulate Minnesota 13 
Power as it always has?  14 
A. No. The  Commission’s authority is unchanged,  and Minnesota Power would remain 15 
regulated by the Commission  post-Acquisition. Further, in the December 19, 2024,  16 
Order from the FERC approving this Acquisition, the FERC affirme d, “Following the 17 
completion of the Proposed Transaction, Applicants will remain under the regulatory  18 
oversight of both the Commission and state commissions in the same manner as they 19 
are curren tly.”5 20 
 21 
Q. Did any Parties raise concerns regarding the regulatory compact in Party 22 
Testimony?  23 
A. Yes. Department Witness Vavro  stated,  “[p]roposed  governance structures fail to reflect 24 
the regulatory compact, which balances the needs  of the public and the utility.”6 Witness 25 
Vavro writes that as a publicly traded company ALLETE’s focus is largely directed to 26 
the activities  of its two regulated utilities. However,  Witness Vavro notes that if the 27 
Acquisition is approved , ALLETE will be owned  by private eq uity funds with a broader 28 
scope and uncertain priorities. Finally, W itness Vavro states “ [t]he Parties imply that 29 
 
5 ALLETE, Inc. & Alloy Parent LLC , EC24 -105-000, FERC ¶ 49 (2024) , available online at 
https://www.ferc.gov/media/e -14-ec24 -105-000. 
6 DOC Ex. ___ (SV) at 4 (“ Vavro Direct ”).  
 
 9 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  Minnesota Power’s obligation to comply with the Commission’s rules and regulations 1 
should be somehow different when they own the utility.”7 2 
 3 
Q. What is your response to Witness Vavro’s statements regarding the A cquisition’s 4 
impact on  the regulatory compact?  5 
A. To be clear, neither  the Company nor the Partners have ever stated that Minnesota 6 
Power’s obligation to comply with the Commission’s rules and regulations would be 7 
different post -Acquisition. To the contrary, in both the July 19, 2024,  Petition and in 8 
Direct Testimony, Minnesota Power and the Partners recognize the ongoing authority 9 
of state and federal regulators over the regulated utility. As noted in my Direct 10 
Testimony, investors play an important role in the energy industry by providing capital 11 
to finance upgrades and modernization of aging infrastructure, build out of new 12 
infrastructure and the operation of public utilities’ business.8 ALLETE’s current 13 
investors can purchase and sell shares of ALLETE at any time. The changing of 14 
investors – whether it be individual public market investors or the change to private 15 
equity investors – does not inherently alter the regulated nature of a public utility. As 16 
noted above and confirmed by FERC Order, the proposed Acquisition results in no 17 
change to the jurisdictional regulation of Minnesota Power by the Commission , nor does 18 
it change the applicability of state and federal energy policy to the regulated utility. The 19 
regulatory compact is simply un affect ed by the changing of ALLETE’s investors . 20 
Finally, both the Company and the Partners have offered additional commitments in this 21 
proceeding to demonstrate their respect for the regulatory compact and the regulatory 22 
framework in Minnesota.  23 
 24 
Q. Did any Party  Testimony  identify benefits associated with the existing regulatory 25 
compact?  26 
A. Yes. LiUNA Witness  Erin Bryant  stated :  27 
we believe that Minnesota’s strong system and culture of utility 28 
regulation not only protects customers an d workers from risks that can 29 
accompany other corporate acquisition, but also substantially aligns the 30 
 
7 Vavro Direct at 11. 
8 MP Ex. ____ (JJC) at 6 (“ Cady Direct ”).  
 
 10 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  interest of the utility’s new owners with the public’s interest in a well- 1 
run utility. Unlike investors  in a non -regulated business, ALLETE’s 2 
new owners will not have the ability to raise prices, add leverage, drop 3 
customers, or scale back services without Public Utility Commission 4 
approval. Instead, the best and clearest path to growing the value of a 5 
well-regulated utility is sound management and growth  of beneficial 6 
electric load through retention and recruitment of  large customers  to 7 
share infrastructure costs.9 8 
 9 
V. ENERGY POLICY CONSIDERATIONS  10 
Q. Do you have a response to CURE Witness Jim Baker ’s assertion that it seems 11 
Minnesota Power’s core values and commitments to employees, customers, 12 
communities and the climate are at risk under private equity ownership?10 13 
A. Yes. Witness Baker notes that private equity firms are motivated to deliver targeted 14 
returns for their investors and there are no legal guardrails guaranteeing that the Partners 15 
will operate in accordance with ALLETE’s values. ALLETE is publicly traded on the 16 
stock market today with thousands of individual investors who are also motivated to 17 
receive a return on their investment. Having investors who expect a fair return on their 18 
investment in no way prevents Minnesota Power from remaining a values -based 19 
business committed to its customers, communities and the climate. Further, private 20 
equity ownership by the Partners provides more certainty on the alignment of values 21 
than public market ownership as the Partners have provided sworn testimony that they 22 
are, in fact, supportive of Minnesota Power’s values and leadership team . Minnesota 23 
Power’s leadership team witnessed  the Partners demonstrate these values since signing 24 
the Merger Agreement  in 2024, by spending time with Company  employees , customers 25 
and, community leaders across our service territory and being willing to engage  26 
collaboratively  with all interested parties to address concerns related the Acquisition.  27 
 28 
 
9 LIUNA Ex. ____ (EB) at 9 (“ Bryant Direct ”).  
10 CURE Ex. _____ (JB) at 25 (“ Baker Direct ”).  
 
 11 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  Q. Since announcing the proposed Acquisition of ALLETE  in 2024 , has Minnesota 1 
Power continued executing its ambitious Energy Forward  strategy?  2 
A. Yes. In fact, on March 3, 2025, the Company filed its most recent Integrated Resource 3 
Plan (“IRP”) in Docket No. E015/RP -25-127 and announced  the next chapter in its 4 
Energy Forward  strategy . The IRP covers the planning period of 2025 -2039 and outlines 5 
a path  forward to continue its plan to cease all coal operations by 2035 and mak e 6 
continued progress in complying with Minnesota’s 2040 Carbon Free Standard 7 
(“CFS”). Minnesota Power’s 2025 IRP charts a path for the Company to be 90 percent 8 
compliant with Minnesota’s  CFS by adding significant amounts of new renewable and 9 
energy storage resources and maintaining the near -perfect system reliability that 10 
customers expect.  11 
 12 
Q. Does Sierra Club Witness Courtney Lane provide testimony on the relationship 13 
between the Acquisition and investments in generation resources?  14 
A. Yes. Witness Lane recommends the Commission not approve the Acquisition. Included 15 
in Witness Lane’s  reasoning is the statement that, “ [t]he Partners’ incentive to increase 16 
profits in the short term would likely lead to over investment in capital investments as 17 
opposed to demand -side solutions like greater efficiency or non -capital approaches like 18 
power purchase agreements (“PPA”) from third parties.”11 Witness Lane also testifies 19 
that the proposed Acquisition could threaten Minnesota Power’s ability to meet state 20 
carbon reduction goals as “there is no guarantee that future owners would follow 21 
through on current plans to retire Minnesota Power’s coal fleet” and that there is “a risk 22 
that the Partners will not follow through on their stated commitments to clean energy.”12  23 
 24 
Q. Do you have a response to this portion of Witness Lane’s testimony?  25 
A. Yes. Minnesota Power’s resource plans, energy efficiency and conservation programs, 26 
individual large power customer contracts , and individual resource additions are all 27 
within the Commission’s jurisdiction and require Commission approval prior to 28 
implementation. This is true today and would be true post -Acquisition.  29 
 
11 SIERRA Ex. ____ (CL) at 4 (“ Lane Direct ”).  
12 Lane Direct at 4.  
 
 12 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule   1 
Neither ALLETE’s current owners, nor the Partners if the Acquisition were approved, 2 
have the ability to direct rate -recovered investments or power plant retirement dates 3 
without Commission approval. Further, as evidenced by the recent filing of the 4 
Company’s latest IRP, Minnesota Power is moving forward with its plan to cease all 5 
coal generation on its system by 2035 , and continuing to make significant progress 6 
towards meeting Minnesota’s CFS . 7 
 8 
 Meeting the CFS will require a lot of investment to deliver successfully, including new 9 
generation, new transmission, upgrades to distribution systems, and investments into 10 
new clean technologies. The Acquisition is a critical part of our strategy to make these 11 
investments, and our ability to do so will be limited if the Acquisition is not approved.  12 
 13 
VI. IMPACT OF THE ACQUISITION ON MINNESOTA POWER RATES 14 
Q. When considering ALLETEs need for capital, is th ere a direct correlation  between 15 
that need for capital and  the electric rates  paid by Minnesota Power customers ? 16 
A. No. While there is a significant need for capital to facilitate the clean energy transition, 17 
not all investments in ALLETE’s capital plan will be recovered from Minnesota Power 18 
customers directly. For example, other non -regulated ALLETE business u nits like 19 
ALLETE Clean Energy and New Energy Equity have their own capital needs that are 20 
completely unrelated to Minnesota Power’s business but would also benefit from  this 21 
Acquisition . That said, a substantial amount of ALLETE’s capital needs do come from 22 
the regulated utility  as it works to cease the use of coal – its primary source of baseload 23 
power generation – at its Boswell Energy Facility, and to meet state policy goals and 24 
comply with Minnesota’s CFS, which will require significant buildout of new resources 25 
for capacity replacement at Boswell .  26 
 27 
Even so , not all of Minnesota Power’s  own capital investments are directly recovered 28 
from its 150,000 retail electric customers. As the most recent example, on January 23, 29 
2025,  the Commission held a hearing in which it approved the Northland Reliability 30 
Project, where  Minnesota Power and Great River Energy are co -applicants to construct 31 
 
 13 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Cady Rebuttal and Schedule  a 140-mile double circuit 245 kV transmission line. This transmission line was 1 
identified in the Mid -Continent Independent System Operator , Inc ’s (“MISO”) Long 2 
Range T ransmission Plan (“LRTP”)  to provide broad regional benefits to the 3 
transmission system . As such, the costs of the project , estimated to cost over $1 billion  4 
to construct (2022$) , will be recovered from all MISO transmission owners  in the 5 
participating region . While Minnesota Power requires the capital to construct this line 6 
and its customers will benefit from the regional reliability it brings, Minnesota Power 7 
customers will only pay their portion of MISO cost allocation, which is roughly two 8 
percent of the total project costs  based on current load contributions to MISO under the 9 
tariff . The Company also will be participating in the ownership, construction, and 10 
operation of  three  transmission projects included in MISO’s LRTP Tranche 2 .1 that will 11 
require significant capital,  with the costs similarly shared across MISO members  due to 12 
their broad regional benefits . As is discussed in more detail in Company Witness 13 
Taran’s rebuttal testimony,  the capital required to build transmission projects alone is 14 
significant, with current estimates of over $3  billion for the following four MISO LRTP 15 
cost-allocated projects  of which Minnesota Power is a part : the Northland Reliability 16 
Project, Bison – Alexandria 345 kV project, Maple River – Cuyuna 345 kV project and 17 
the Iron Range – St Louis Count y – Arrowhead 345 kV project.  18 
 19 
Q. Did any Party  Testimony identify concerns over rates and affordability?  20 
A. Yes. LPI Witness Walters concludes that one potential harm of the proposed Acquisition 21 
is the effect on customer rates. Witness Walters  notes, “ [t]he contemplated capital 22

A. For the potential harm noted above to come to fruition, the Commission would have to 5 
fully abdicate its duties in setting  just and reasonable rates for customers by approving 6 
proposal s that w ere directly opposed to the public interest , both in terms of approving 7 
specific projects and investments and also in approving cost recovery proposals . It is 8 
Minnesota Power’s position that the Commission will execute its duties as outlined in 9 
Minnesota state law to set just and reasonable rates  as it always has . Witness Walters 10 
seems to acknowledge that the utility cannot unilaterally charge customers however it 11

amount of future rate increases .”16 14

Q. Is there  a historical precedent of electric  utility  rates increasing after a transition 16 
from being publicly traded to be ing privately owned?  17 
A. No. In fact, when looking at several recent electric utilities that have transitioned from 18 
being publicly traded to privately owned,  electric rates did not meaningfully increase  19 
and in many cases were better than comparable average rates . Several examples are 20 
offered below, including El Paso Electric (both Texas and New Mexico utilities), 21 
CLECO Power, Duquesne Light Company and Puget Sound Energy . When  looking at 22 
the five investor owned electric utilities below that have been acquired since 200 7, their 23 
collective Compound Annual Growth Rate (“CAGR”) averaged 1. 62 percent per year  24 
from the year of acquisition , which is not only well below the rate of inflation but also 25 
lower than their respective statewide averages and national investor owned utility 26 
averages over the same time period , as shown in Table 1 .  27

Q. Please summarize your Rebuttal Testimony.  13 
A. As described in previous testimony, ALLETE proactively identified a strategy to partner 14 
with new investors  that could support the enti re family of ALLETE business es in 15 
executing their individual strategies, including Minnesota Power. Minnesota Power has 16 
operated in a way that supports its customers, communities and the climate and 17 
ALLETE intentionally chose these Partners – CPP Investments and GIP – because they 18 
were aligned with  those  core values, supported the Company’s strategy, and had the 19 
ability to help all of ALLETE’s businesses execute their future plans. Minnesota Power 20 
and the Partners have listened earnestly to Parties’ concerns and offered tangible and 21 
meaningful commitments  in an attempt to address them. However, some concerns 22 
identified in Party  Testimony lacked a grounding in the reality of what it means to 23 
operate as a regulated public utility in the State of Minnesota. Neither the Partners nor 24 
Minnesota Power can unilaterally raise customers’ electric rates for investments that are 25 
not deemed to be in the public interest. Further, the foundational assumption underlying  26 
that hypothetical scenario is that Minnesota Power would support  and advocate for  an 27 
unjust outcome for customers for the purpose of garnering  inflated profits for its 28 
investors and that is simply false. Mi nnesota Power is proud to serve the customers and 29 
communities of Northern Minnesota and will continue to do so with integrity , as it has 30 
for more than a hundred years, regardless of who its investors are.  31

•Second, in light of various parties’ commentary about the need for clear commitments to the  regulatory compact, on Pages 6-7 Minnesota Power and the Partners list responsive affirmations intended to
underscore their ongoing commitment to the obligations of Minnesota Power that  currently exist  and that will continue  after the Acquisition . As there  are many applicable laws, rules, orders, policies, and past
commitments that govern Minnesota Power’s obligations to its customers, the Commission, and other stakeholder s, this list is not intended to every possible continuing obligation but to illustrate the Company’s
and the Partners’ overall commitment to the regulatory compact and the authority of the Commission.

Financial 
Commitments 
to Minnesota 
Power  1.To alleviate concerns about the availability of investment funds, Alloy Parent
commits to provide to M innesota Power  equity financing, including but not limited
to equity infusion, deferral or reinvestment of dividends, or a combination of both,
in an amount at least equal to the equity financing required to fund Minnesota
Power’s 5 -year capital investment plan reflecte d in its February 2025 10 -K filing,
subject to prospective reasonable and prudent plan adjustments.
The Partners are able to make this commitment with the understanding that this 
funding commitment will not be used to establish a higher or lower ROE. The 
Partners do not intend to suggest that there are any limits on the Commission’s 
authority to establish an ROE or for parties to advocate  for reasonable returns 
consistent with legal requirements, but it would be unreasonable to accept a 
funding commitment and then use the commitment as a basis to reduce the returns.   Scissons Rebuttal  Sec. VI.  
Alley Rebuttal Sec. III. B.  
Bram Rebuttal Sec. II. 
Quackenbush Rebuttal Sec.  B. This commitment ensures that Minnesota Power will have access to the equity it needs. Absent 
this Acquisition, Minnesota Power, through ALLETE, will need to make serial common equity 
offerings. Since the Company’s stock was first listed on the New York Stock Exchange in 1950 
(nearly 75 years ago), the Company has raised approximately $1.3 billion through follow -on 
common equity offerings. To fund the billions of dollars  necessary for the implementation of 
Minnesota Power’s five -year capital plan, Minnesota Power would need to raise approximately 
$1 billion through follow -on common equity offerings over the next five years. These offerings 
will be subject to whatever the market will bear at that time, which could be detrimental to 
Minnesota Power’s customers.  
No investor in the public market is able to make this kind of commitment.  The Partners’ interest 
in the Company is tied to its current functions as a utility, including its ability to generate stable 
returns commensurate with other utilities of comparable risk profiles and reasonable growth 
opportunities, thereby contributing in  its own way to broader, diverse holdings of GIP and CPP 
Investments. Further, the Partners recognize that the success of this investment can only occur if 
Minnesota Power is adequately funded.    
2.Minnesota Power will provide compliance filing s on equity infusions from  and
dividends to  Alloy Parent in the same manner that the Company currently provides
compliance filings in its capital structure docket.Cady Rebuttal at Sec. VII. 
Anderson Rebuttal Sec. II. C. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. II. Minnesota Power will be ensuring transparency regarding equity and dividends . 
Capital Structure 
(Equity and Debt) 3.ALLETE will not make any dividend or distribution that would cause the actual
equity ratio of Minnesota Power to be outside the range approved by the
Commission.Alley Rebuttal Sec. III.A. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. III. 
Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX.  Although the Company makes annual capital structure filings and ALLETE is required to 
manage within that range, ALLETE has no current regulatory limitation on when it may 
make any dividend or distribution.  This commitment will ensure that no dividends or 
distributions are issued that could impair ALLETE’s financial viability.  
4.The Company commits to not make any dividend or distributions unless at least
one senior unsecured credit rating is investment grade or above.Alley Rebuttal Sec. III.A. This commitment protects the Company’s credit rating, and therefore the cost of debt, and limits 
the Partners’ ability to take distributions.  
5.If Minnesota Power’s cost of debt increases above current levels within three
years following the close of the Acquisition, Minnesota ratepayers will be held
harmless from any rate impact unless Minnesota Power can demonstrate that
its increased cost of de bt was not caused by the Acquisition.Taran Rebuttal  Sec. III. D. 
Alley Rebuttal Sec. III.F. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. III. This provision protects customers if the cost of debt were to change as a result of the Acquisition .

corporate and facility ratings.Lapson Direct Schedule 3  
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.   This commitment will help ensure reasonable costs of capital for customers, as well as 
stakeholder insight into the Company’s financial health.  
7.ALLETE will use commercially reasonable efforts to remain rated by at least
two credit rating agencies.Lapson Direct 15:8-14 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  Currently, Minnesota Power has no regulatory obligation to remain rated by at least two credit 
rating agencies. This commitment will help ensure reasonable costs of capital for customers, as 
well as stakeholder insight into the Company’s financial health.

19. Regarding energy affordability for residential customers, there will be no reduction 
in Minnesota Power’s currently designed affordability program budget (formally 
referred to as the Customer Affordability of Residential Electricity program or 
“CARE”) or the current CARE program eligibility process for the duration of the 
Partner s’ ownership of ALLETE.   Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX.  
Alley Rebuttal Sec. III.I. 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  This commitment ensures that there is no reduction in service or benefits for low -income 
customers who participate  in the CARE program . This proposal provides customers with 
assurance that such program budgets or program eligibility will remain intact so long as the 
Partners own ALLETE.  
20. In addition, the Partners will provide a financial contribution with the objective to 
significantly reduce residential arrears to pre -COVID -19 balances or lower, an 
outcome that would benefit all Minnesota Power customers while providing 
account balance re lief to the most economically challenged residential customers. 
This contribution will be used to temporarily augment the flat $20 discount and 
Arrearage Forgiveness components of Minnesota Power’s CARE program. A 
similar arrearage forgiveness offering wil l be developed on a limited scope and 
duration basis for non -income qualified residential customers that successfully 
enter into and complete a 24 -month payment arrangement for arrears, pending 
confirmation of billing system capability and reasonable level  of effort. A guiding 
principle shall be to leverage existing program design and system processes to the 
greatest extent possible to maximize dollars that will directly benefit eligible 
customers. Drawing from the tremendous success of the collaborative st akeholder 
engagement process used to develop and propose previous modifications to CARE, 
Minnesota Power will coordinate with the Commission’s Consumer Affairs Office 
and the EnergyCENTS Coalition to refine this proposal and offering, inclusive of 
eligibil ity criteria and outreach plans. Details will be shared with the other 
nonprofit organizations and interested stakeholders previously involved with 
CARE modifications for their input and awareness prior to implementation. This 
financial contribution from t he Partners may be made in whole or in multiple 
installments over a period of up to two years following system implementation and 
customer outreach, contingent upon the Commission’s order approving this 
transaction. The total financial contribution is not to exceed the total balance of 
residential customer arrears as of the approval date.  Cady Rebuttal Sec. IX. 
Alley Rebuttal Sec. III.I 
Bram Rebuttal Sec. X.  This commitment was developed in partnership with EnergyCENTS Coalition and provides a 
new, historic  shareholder benefit of up to $3.5 million  to the Company’s most vulnerable 
customers, helping them erase long -standing residential arrearages. This is a first -of-its-kind 
commitment  that provides benefits to residential customers that would otherwise be born by 
other customers. The intent of this commitment  is to help Minnesota Power customers reduce 
arrears to pre -COVID -19 balances or lower .

Q. Please state your name , employer, and position . 2 
A. My name is Jeffery J. Scissons . I am employed by ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota 3

 5 
Q. Did you provide Direct Testimony in this proceeding?  6 
A. Yes. 7

IR 0004, which is attached to my testimony as Rebuttal Schedule 5) is Efficient Market 2 
Hypothesis originally published by Dr. Euguene Fama in 1970.15 This theory has been 3 
heavily debated in Business Schools around the world and calling it “accepted financial 4 
theory” is grossly inaccurate. A simple Google search will display the amount of 5 
discussion on the topic opposing and supporting the hypothesis. Using this premise  to 6 
counter the concerns around stock market volatility is inconsistent with logic.  7 
 8 
Dr. Fama himself said, in an interview with Chicago Booth Review in 2016, “ That’s the 9 
statement of the hypothesis, but it’s a model. It’s not completely true. No models are 10 
completely true.”16 Fellow renowned economist Robert Thaler who participated in the 11 
same interview is an expert in behavioral economics and is in disagreement with 12 
Efficient Market Hypothesis. The example used in Thaler’s book Misbehaving: The 13 
Making of Behavioral Economics  highlighted, when referencing the 1987 stock market 14 
crash, “ It’s hard to argue the price at the close trading on Thursday, October 15, and the 15 
price at the close of trading the following Monday, more than 25 percent lower, can 16 
both be rational measures of intrinsic value, given the absence of news.”17 As Thaler 17 
continued, “unpredictable doesn’t mean rational.”18 The debate is also captured in a 18 
2024 article from the CFA Institute by Scott Lanigan in 2024.19 As these post -1970 19 
articles demonstrate, the theory on which Witness Addonizio relies continues to be 20 
debated today and is not “accepted  financial theory .”20  21

Reference Quackenbush Direct at  15:4-12: You refer here to the difference between an “occasional 
issuer ” and a “ serial issuer. ”  
(a)Define each term.
(b)You say that ALLETE  is a serial issuer.  Is it a serial issuer because of its 40% role as a merchant 
seller, its 60% role as a state -franchised monopoly utility, or because of the combination of 
the two? Explain your answer.
(c)Which of the two types would be Minnesota Power  be if it were a pure -play utility rather than
a 60% division of ALLETE ?
R
esponse:  
(a)Occasional issuer means an issuer that issues infrequently, perhaps every 3 -5 years or even
less often.  Serial issuer means an issuer with perpetually repeating issuance needs,
perhaps with a need to issue every year or even more often.
(
b)ALLETE is a serial issuer because of its disproportionate outsized capital expenditure needsas identified in its five -year capital plan as well as its 20 -year Sustainability -in-Action
strategy.  The capital plan is driven by a combination of all ALLETE’s divisions andsubsidiaries.  However, as noted on page 16, lines 23 -24 of my Direct Testimony, 87% of
ALLETE’s five -year capital plan is driven by Minnesota Power.
(
c)Minnesota Power’s capital needs would be the same whether it is structured as a divisionof ALLETE or a pure -play utility, so Minnesota Power would be a serial issuer either way.

QUEST:  
The following statement appears in Mr. Addonizio’s testimony: “Their largest stated 
concern, regarding stock market volatility and market inefficiencies, is unsupported by evidence or 
analysis and is contrary to accepted financial theory and evidence from investor returns.”  Please 
identify the source of the “accepted financial theory” including the primary proponent of this referenced theory.   
RES
PONSE:  
The Efficient Market Hypothesis (“EMH”), the “accepted financial theory” to which Mr. 
Addonizio was referring, is primarily credited to Dr. Eugene Fama . Mr. Addonizio does not have 
copy of Dr. Fama’s original paper on this topic, “Efficient Capital Markets: A Review of Theory and Empirical Work,” published in 1970 in the Journal of Finance. However, the theory is discussed in numerous other publications,  including Zvi Bodie et al., I
NVESTMENTS  at 348 -9 (8th ed. 20 09). 
Mr. A
ddonizio is not sure who is currently considered the primary proponent of this theory, 
though Dr. Fama is likely a top proponent.

Taran  Rebuttal and Schedules  I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name , employer, and position . 2 
A. My name is Joshua D. Taran , and I am employed by ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota 3 
Power1 as Manager – Financial Planning.  4 
 5 
Q. Did you provide Direct Testimony in this proceeding?  6 
A. Yes. 7 
 8 
Q. What is the purpose of your testimony?  9 
A. I am providing Rebuttal Testimony in response to  Party Direct Testimony (“Party 10 
Testimony”)  claims regarding the Company’s capital needs and access  to capital . I’ll 11 
discuss reasons why the Acquisition continues to present the best path forward for the 12 
Company and its stakeholders. Then I’ll respond directly to Party Testimony  in this 13 
case. I’ll begin with a response to the Department  of Commerce ( the “ Department ”), 14 
due to overlapping concerns with other Parties , and then provide responses to the O ffice 15 
of the Attorney General (“OAG ”), the Large Power Intervenor s (“LPI”), and Sierra 16 
Club , in turn.2 17 
 18 
Q. Are you sponsoring any exhibits in this proceeding?  19 
A. Yes. I am sponsoring the following schedules to my Rebuttal Testimony:  20 
• MP Exhibit ___ ( JDT), Rebuttal Schedule 1 – MP Response to DOC IR 0008 ; 21 
• MP Exhibit ___ ( JDT), Rebuttal Schedule 2 – MP Response to DOC IR 0015 ; 22 
• MP Exhibit ___ (JDT), Rebuttal Schedule 3 – MP Response to DOC IR 0018 ; 23 
• MP Exhibit ___ (JDT), Rebuttal Schedule 4 – MP Response to DOC IR 0019;  24 
 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this Rebuttal  Testimony and the 
Petition, “Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota. Unless otherwise specifically 
defined, references to “ALLETE” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota 
Power and all reg ulated and non -regulated subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, 
Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
2 Based on CUB’s  Response to the Motion to Strike and Revoke Access,  dated  February 25, 2025, I understand 
that CUB has withdrawn Scott Hempling’s pre -filed Direct Testimony and no longer plans to file further testimony 
from him.  Because CUB has withdrawn t hat testimony, Minnesota Power and the Partners do not address it  in 
rebuttal and instead focus on other witnesses’ testimony.   
 
 2 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran  Rebuttal and Schedules  • MP Exhibit ___ (JDT), Rebuttal Schedule 5 – MP Response to DOC IR 0020; 1 
and 2 
• MP Exhibit ___ (JDT), Rebuttal Schedule 6 – S&P Global Ratings’ 2025 3 
Industry Credit Outlook for North American Regulated Utilities . 4 
 5 
II. NEED FOR THE ACQUISITION  6 
Q. What is the purpose of this section of your Rebuttal Testimony?  7 
A. In general, I observe that several Parties question the Company’s need for access to 8 
capital, and the level of capital that is available to it in the public markets versus from 9 
this Acquisition.  In particular, Parties express concern that the Company’s capital 10 
expenditure forecast is uncertain, suggest ways that capital needs could be reduced, and 11 
question the benefits of accessing capital from the Partners.  12 
 13 
Q.  In general, what concerns did Intervenors express about the need for the 14 
Acquisition?  15 
A.  Other Parties to this proceeding  seem to doubt whether there is a need for the 16 
Acquisition and , in particular , whether ALLETE needs to improve its access to equity 17 
capital  – the primary purpose for the Acquisition.  18 
 19 
This line of thinking is troubling. The senior management, executive leadership, and 20 
Board of ALLETE have been engaged in a multiple -years -long effort to evaluate what 21 
we need in order to provide safe, reliable, and affordable service to customers while 22 
accomplishing Minnesota’s policy requirements for public utilities. This group of 23 
people reached the conclusion that a change was required. ALLETE  then engaged in a 24 
years -long process to identify the best investors, ones who would allow the Company  25 
to remain a small, unique utility focused on Northern Minnesota.  26 
 27 
The foundation of this decision -making process was the analysis that the Company 28 
cannot rely on the public markets going forward and needs a better and more reliable 29 
source of equity capital. In reaching this conclusion, the ALLETE team relied upon  30 
 
 3 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran  Rebuttal and Schedules  first-hand knowledge of the upcoming capital needs,  substantial experience in working 1 
with public markets, and was able to draw on the expertise of trusted financial advisors.  2 
 3 
In my Rebuttal Testimony, I provide more information about why the Company needs 4 
improved access to capital. The fact that some Parties  have doubts  should not minimize 5 
the careful analysis that was done to reach the foundational conclusion that Minnesota 6 
Power  need s better access to capital. The suggestion that the Company is somehow 7 
simply wrong, and actually does not need better access to capital, is not reasonable. It 8 
is also extremely risky, which the other Parties  do not seem to recognize. If the 9 
Acquisition is not approved, the Company may not have access to the capital it requires 10 
to ensure it can meet Minnesota’s requirements and continue to provide safe, reliable, 11 
and affordable service.  12 
 13 
Q. Before responding to Party Testimony , would you please provide context for the 14 
Company’s capital need s? 15 
A. Yes. Since providing Direct Testimony  in this proceeding , the Company’s need for 16 
capital has only become clearer . While other Parties to the case have suggested that the 17 
status quo would be sufficient to access the necessary  capital going forward,3 that 18 
reasoning fails to recognize the changes in capital needs in the future compared to what 19 
has occurred  in the past. In fact, since the Company’s stock was first listed on the New 20 
York Stock Exchange in 1950  (nearly 75 years ago) , the Company has raised 21 
approximately $1.3 billion through follow -on common equity offerings .4 To fund the 22 
Company’s $4.8 billion five -year capital plan , the Company  will need over $1 billion 23 
in common equity over the next five years, which would require annual secondary 24 
offerings.  25 
 26 
Those capital projects  are driven by unprecedented circumstances, including 27 
Minnesota’s 2040 Carbon Free Standard (“CFS”) , coal plant retirements,  significant 28 
 
3 DOC Ex. __ ( CMA)  at 3 (“ Addonizio Direct ”); SIERA Ex. __  (CL)  at 12 -13 (“Lane Direct ”). 
4 This figure includes common stock  issued through  secondary offerings  the Company’s At -The-Market Program . 
 
 4 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran  Rebuttal and Schedules  transmission and distribution system needs,  inflation, and  other rising costs and 1 
investment requirements . 2 
 3 
As one of the smallest publicly traded utilities in the Country, it is unlikely that the 4 
Company will be able to readily access the necessary equity in the public marketplace. 5 
For context, ALLETE has needed to issue equity via large secondary offerings on three 6 
occasions over the prior 25 years ( $156 million in 20 01, $160 million in 2014, and $232 7 
million in 2022). To manage the future equity needs, the Company would need a 8 
secondary equity offering at amounts greater than any of the prior issuances , on an 9 
annual basis. Even if the capital expenditures are overstated – which we do not believe 10 
they are – there would be a need for the Company to find significant sources of 11 
additional equity capital that are not likely readily  available in the marketplace or 12 
available with the flexibility necessary for a company of ALLETE’s size.  13 
 14 
Q. Since your Direct Testimony was filed, h ave there been any updates in the 15 
Company’s capital forecasts that further underscore the Company’s need for 16 
significant future capital ? 17 
A. Yes. As is standard practice, the Company updated its five -year capital expenditure 18 
forecast for inclusion in its annual report and Capital Structure Petition filing . In my 19 
Direct Testimony, Figure 1 showed ALLETE’s regulated capital expenditures need as 20 
$4.2 billion for the 2024 to 2028 time period. The updated projections reflect 21 
$4.8 billion for regulated services for the 2025 to 2029 time period .5 While this increase 22 
is largely driven by the shift in years ( the inclusion of  2029 and removal of  2024), it 23 
also reflects the Company’s latest projections and information regarding future capital 24 
projects.  While these projections will continue to be refined  and updated as additional 25 
information becomes available, one thing is clear: the need for capital is real and 26 
extensive.  Table 1 below quantifies th is updated data . Further, it shows that the 27 
 
5 See ALLETE, Form 10 -K at 62, Feb. 13, 2024, Securities Exchange Commission, available at 
https://investor.allete.com/node/22956/html ; In the Matter of Petition for Approval of Minnesota Power’s 2025 
Capital Structure Petition , Docket No.  E015/S -25-138, PETITION  at Ex. L  (Feb. 28, 2025).  
 
 5 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran  Rebuttal and Schedules  Acquisition is needed even within a wide band of accuracy around these capital 1 
forecasts.  2 
 3 
Table 1 – Regulated Capital Expenditure Forecasts ($ millions)  4 
 
2025  2026  2027  2028  2029  Total  
Regulated Utility Operations        
High kV Transmission Expansion            90          200          615          635          265       1,805  
Solar RFP          145          180            60            40              -            425

 5 
Q. How does the amount of equity available from the Partners differ from the equity 6 
historically availab le to ALLETE in public markets?  7 
A. Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure 8 
Partners (“GIP”) (together, the “Partners”)  are aware of the level of equity needed for 9 
Minnesota Power to complete these necessary capital projects  and have adequate funds 10 
to provide equity infusions into the Company  on a regular basis . In contrast, seeking 11 
such levels of funding in public markets would introduce significant risks as I'll describe 12 
in detail below in response to Party positions .  13 
 14 
Q. Have the Partners offered additional commitments that underscore the value of 15 
the Acquisition and the benefits of private capital investment?  16 
A. Yes. As discussed in the Rebuttal Testimony of Partner Witnesses Jonathan Bram and 17 
Andrew Alley, the Partners have expressly agreed to provide sufficient capital to fund 18 
the Company’s five -year capital plan , subject to all existing Commission regulation and 19 
decision -making regarding the degree of cost recovery and revenue allocation applied 20 
to customers. In short, the Partners are making the capital available  subject to the long - 21 
standing regulatory framework in Minnesota that protects customers from any 22 
investments that are not just  and reasonable in the provision of utility service. No 23 
investor in the public markets can make such a commitment to the Company or its 24 
customers. This means the Compan y (and customers) will have access to the equity 25 
 
 6 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran  Rebuttal and Schedules  capital they need to meet state requirements and goals without the uncertaint ies inherent 1 
in seeking the necessary equity in the public markets , while remaining the same 2 
Minnesota Power utility company  anchored in the communities it serves and fully 3 
subject to  the Commission’s regulatory  authority.  4 
 5 
Q. In light of this backdrop, d o you have general concerns regarding Party 6 
Testimony?  7 
A. Yes, I  am concerned that  Party Testimony  offered in this proceeding often focuses on 8 
theory or citations to textbooks as opposed to the real -world considerations I must 9 
account for every day in my work. In my role at ALLETE as Manager of Financial 10 
Planning, I work to ensure that Minnesota Power remains financially healthy so it can 11 
meet its obligations under the law and its commitments to the customers  and 12 
communities it serves. This includes work ing to ensure the Company can maintain its 13 
investment grade credit rating, minimizing exposure to adverse market conditions, 14 
maintaining a strong liquidity profile, and be ing well situated to access the capital 15 
necessary to serve our customers in the future.  16 
 17 
III. RESPONSE TO THE DEPARTMENT  18 
A. Access to Capital  19 
Q. Please summarize Department Witness  Addonizio’s testimony as it relates to 20 
capital access.  21 
A. Witness  Addonizio claims that the Company’s access to capital will not be improved  22 
by the Acquisition.  This assertion  is based  on claim s that the Partners have not made 23 
any commitment to provide capital to ALLETE  and that patient capital was not 24 
explained adequately, as well as  his mistaken belie f that public markets provide better 25 
capital availability than the Partners.  26 
 27 
Q. What concerns do you have regarding Witness  Addonizio’s conclusions?  28 
A.  Witness Addonizio’s claims are based solely on theory and without appreciation for the 29 
actual difficulties of raising  over $1 billion  in equity from no less than annual equity 30 
issuances in the face of turbulent markets. Unlike Witness Addonizio, ALLETE has the 31 
 
 7 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Taran  Rebuttal and Schedules  actual experience and the actual responsibility to raise the needed equity on which 1 
customer service and achievement of state policy depend. The Company’s  carefully 2 
weighed decision to move to private equity reflected a combination of factors, including 3 
our responsibility, our experience, awareness of the unprecedented level and change in 4 
our capital expenditures and advice from experienced and knowledgeable advisors.  5

Q. Why does  the Company not just cut its dividend payments now ? 11

dividend payments that provide a steady income stream. Reducing the dividend as a 13 
public company would  likely only serve to reduce investor interest in ALLETE  and fail 14 
to produce long -term benefits regarding capital access.  In fact,  dividend cuts have 15 
proven to cause steep decreases in the share price of other companies  in the past . As 16 
further demonstrated in the Rebuttal Testimony of Company and Partner Witness 17 
Quackenbush, the overwhelming reaction of the public equity market to dividend cuts 18 
is to punish the stock price of the utility cutting its dividend.  Issuing additional shares 19 
at a depressed price would have the circular impact of causing additional dividend 20 
obligations due to the need to issue a larger number of shares , which fails to provide the 21 
necessary increased cash flow .  22

Power’s projects  as being the most cost -competitive for Minnesota Power customers . 16

and would very likely lead to increase d customer costs  and reduced reliability . 18 
Minnesota Power will only self-develop projects that are chosen to be the least cost and 19 
highest value to customers.   20

Topic:  “Flexibility” of capital sources  
Reference(s):  Petition  at 2 and  6   
Request:  
On pa
ge 2 of the Petition, the Company referenced the “inflexible demands of the capital marketplace” and o n 
page  6 of the Petition  suggested that the Partners will provide  access to “flexible” capital.   
a.Please explain specifically what the Company means by “ flexible ” in this context, how the public capital
market is “inflexible,” and in what sense the capital the Partners will provide is expected to be “flexible.”
b.Please identify and fully describe specific instances in the past when the Company faced difficulties
related to the relative lack of “flexibility” of the public equity markets, and how ratepayers and other
stakeholders were negatively impacted.
Response:  
a.As previously discussed in response to DOC  IR 0014, 0015 and 0018, ALLETE’s capital needs  for the
future are larger relative to its size than any other utility. This places ALLETE  in a unique position where 
its reliance on equity financing through secondary offerings  (i.e., issuing additional stock) can have a 
significant effect on the Company’s financial  outlook.  First , relying on public capital markets exposes
ALLETE to the volatility of  the stock market. Over  the last two years, the AL LETE stock price has traded 
below $48/share and above $67/share , representing a 40  percent  variation over this period  (and
ALLETE’s stock trades at a discount to its peers because of several unique  characteristics of the
Company discussed in the responses to DOC  IR 0014, 0015, and 0018). As  discussed in our response to 
part (b), below, having to issue stock through a secondary offering when our stock price is low has a
material effect on the Company’s financial  outlook, which means the Company has less flexibil ity in
terms of timing of and access  to capital.  Publicly traded  utility stocks are valued on consistency of

 Industry Outlook  
Ratings trends and outlook 
In 2024 , downgrades among North America’s investor -owned regulated utilities outpaced 
upgrades  for the fifth consecutive year  (see chart  8). Most were directly attributable to rising 
wildfire risks, robust capital spending, and challenging regulatory constructs. We expect these 
risks will persist for 2025, further pressuring the industry's credit quality.  
Chart 8 
North America regulated utilities’ u pgrades and d owngrades  
 
Source: S&P Global Ratings . 
Main assumptions about 202 5 and beyond 
Capital spending continues to break records.  We expect capital spending for North America’s 
electric, gas, and water utilities will grow by a compound annual growth rate  (CAGR) of about 10%. 
Accordingly, we expect 2025 capital spending to reflect about $240 billion  (see chart  9). To date, 
the industry’s capital spending has been primarily focused on safety , reliability, and energy 
transition.

1. Record capital spending . 
The industry is heavily invest ing in safety, reliability, energy transition, and data centers. We 
expect this spending will exceed $300 billion before the end of the decade. 
2. Management of regulatory risk. 
This includes constructive rate case orders, minimizing regulatory lag, and earning the 
authorized return on equity  (ROE) . 
3. Climate change increases risks. 
The growing frequency of devastating physical events, including hurricanes, storms, and 
wildfires, is elevating the industry’s credit risks .
