Maple  River – Cuyuna 345 kV  project. This transmission line  is a new, 166-mile  345-kV circuit  that will connect  the Maple 
River Substation near Fargo, ND to the  Cuyuna  Series Compensation Station near Riverton, MN. Minnesota  Power is the 
owner of the Cuyuna Series Compensation Station in Minnesota, which is being constructed as part of the Northland Reliability 
Project, a  joint project  with Great  River Energy. Otter Tail  Power Company is the  owner of the  Maple  River Substation in 
North Dakota. The project in total is estimated to cost approximately $910 million and is expected to be completed by 2033. 
Iron Range  – St. Louis County  – Arrowhead 345kV  project. This transmission line  is a new, 63-mile  345-kV circuit  that will 
connect the Iron Range Substation near Grand Rapids, MN to the St. Louis County Substation near Hermantown, MN, and then 
to the  Arrowhead 345 kV Substation, also near Hermantown, MN. Minnesota  Power is the  owner of the  Iron Range  and 
St. Louis County substations. ATC is the owner of the Arrowhead 345 kV Substation. The project in total is estimated to cost 
approximately $370 million and is expected to be completed by 2032. 
Stinson MSSSC  project. This project  involves modification and expansion of the  existing Stinson Substation in Superior, 
Wisconsin to accommodate  a new modular static  synchronous series compensator (MSSSC) system  and associated substation 
equipment. The  MSSSC system  is a type of grid-enhancing technology that  will provide  power flow capability to replace  the 
existing Stinson phase  shifting transformer. The  project  was identified as an underlying system  improvement  associated with 
LRTP Project  #21 (Iron Range-St  Louis County-Arrowhead Project) in the  second phase  of the  MISO Long Range 
Transmission Plan that  was approved on December 12, 2024. SWL&P is the  owner of the  Stinson Substation. The  project  is 
estimated to cost approximately $58 million and is expected to be completed by 2032.
Investment in ATC. ATC’s most recent 10-year transmission assessment, which covers the years 2024 through 2033, identifies a 
need for between $8.9 billion and $10.9 billion in transmission system investments. These investments by ATC, if undertaken, 
are expected to be funded through a combination of internally generated cash, debt and investor contributions. As opportunities 
arise, we plan to make additional investments in ATC through general capital calls based upon our pro rata ownership interest 
in ATC.
ALLETE Clean Energy
ALLETE  Clean Energy will  pursue  growth through acquisitions or project  development. ALLETE  Clean Energy is targeting 
acquisitions of existing operating portfolios which have a mix of long-term PSAs in place and/or available for repowering and 
recontracting. Further, ALLETE  Clean Energy will  evaluate  actions that  will lead to the  addition of complimentary clean 
energy products and services. At  this time, ALLETE  Clean Energy is focused on actions that  will optimize  its clean energy 
project  portfolio of operating and development  projects, which may include  recontracting, repowering, entering into 
partnerships and divestitures along with continued acquisitions or development  of new projects including wind, solar, energy 
storage or storage ready facilities across North America.
Portions of our ALLETE  Clean Energy business are  experiencing return pressures that  are impacting our earnings per share 
growth from  increased competition, congestion and lower forward price  curves, as a  growing amount  of investment  capital  is 
being directed into wind generation opportunities. In addition, current  and potential  new project  developments can be 
negatively affected by a lower ALLETE stock price, which may result in such projects not being accretive, or otherwise unable 
to satisfy our financial  objectives criteria  to proceed. In response  to these  market  pressures, we  are actively evaluating 
additional growth opportunities to deliver more comprehensive clean energy solutions for customers at ALLETE Clean Energy, 
which may include  wind, solar, storage  solutions, and related energy infrastructure  investments and services. We  believe  that 
the energy industry is entering a  new phase  of growth and that  we are well-positioned to serve  customers and drive  future 
growth at ALLETE. ALLETE Clean Energy will continue to optimize its existing wind energy facility portfolio, advance and 
expand its project  pipeline, and explore  other renewable  energy opportunities to further enhance  its service  offerings, growth 
and profitability.
ALLETE  Clean Energy manages risk by having a  diverse  portfolio of assets, which includes PSA expiration, technology and 
geographic diversity. The current operating portfolio is subject to typical variations in seasonal wind with higher wind resources 
typically available  in the  winter months. The  majority of its planned maintenance  leverages this seasonality and is performed 
during lower wind periods. ALLETE Clean Energy’s current operating portfolio is disclosed in Item 1. Business.

Corporate and Other.
New Energy. New Energy is a  renewable  energy development  company with a  primary focus on solar and storage  facilities 
while also offering comprehensive operations, maintenance and asset management services. New Energy is a leading developer 
of community, commercial  and industrial, and small  utility-scale  renewable  energy projects that  has completed more  than 
575 MW  in its history, totaling more  than $1.4 billion of capital. New Energy currently has a  robust  project  pipeline  with 
greater than 2,000 MW of renewable projects in development across over 20 different states. New Energy adds value through 
cost effective  development  and economies of scale  on project  implementation, bringing national  capabilities to regional  co-
development  partners. New Energy is involved in greenfield development  as well  as acquiring and completing mid-stage  and 
late-stage  renewable  energy projects. New Energy will  continue  its current  strategy of developing, owning and operating 
renewable energy projects.
Investment  in Nobles 2.  Our subsidiary, ALLETE  South Wind, owns a  49 percent  equity interest  in Nobles 2, the  entity that 
owns and operates a  250 MW  wind energy facility in southwestern Minnesota  pursuant  to a 20-year PPA with Minnesota 
Power. We account for our investment in Nobles 2 under the equity method of accounting. (See Note 6. Equity Investments.)
South Shore  Energy. South Shore  Energy, ALLETE’s non-rate  regulated, Wisconsin subsidiary, is developing NTEC, an 
approximately 600 MW proposed combined-cycle natural gas-fired generating facility to be built in Superior, Wisconsin, which 
will be jointly owned by Dairyland Power Cooperative, Basin and South Shore  Energy. Minnesota  Power is expected to 
purchase  approximately 20 percent  of the  facility's output  starting upon completion of the  facility pursuant  to a capacity 
dedication agreement. Construction of NTEC is subject to obtaining additional permits from local, state and federal authorities. 
The total project  cost is estimated to be  approximately $700 million, of which South Shore  Energy will  be responsible  for 
approximately 20 percent. South Shore  Energy’s portion of NTEC  project  costs incurred through December 31, 2024, is 
approximately $10 million.
BNI Energy.  In 2024, BNI Energy sold 3.8 million tons of coal (4.0 million tons in 2023) and anticipates 2025 sales will be 
similar to 2024. BNI Energy operates under cost-plus fixed fee agreements extending through December 31, 2037.
ALLETE  Properties. Our strategy incorporates the  possibility of a  bulk sale  of the  entire  ALLETE  Properties portfolio. 
Proceeds from  a bulk sale  would be  strategically deployed to support  growth initiatives at  our Regulated Operations and 
ALLETE Clean Energy. ALLETE Properties also continues to pursue sales of individual parcels over time and will continue to 
maintain key entitlements and infrastructure.
Income Taxes
ALLETE’s aggregate  federal  and multi-state  statutory tax rate  is approximately 28 percent  for 2024. ALLETE  also has tax 
credits and other tax adjustments that  reduce  the combined statutory rate  to the  effective  tax rate. These  tax credits and 
adjustments historically have  included items such as production tax credits, excess deferred taxes, non-controlling interests in 
subsidiaries, as well as other items. The annual effective rate can also be impacted by such items as changes in income before 
income  taxes, state  and federal  tax law changes that  become  effective  during the  year, business combinations, tax planning 
initiatives and resolution of prior years’ tax matters. We  expect  that our effective  tax rate  will be lower than the  combined 
statutory rate over the next 5 to 10 years due to tax credits attributable to our wind and solar energy generation.

equivalents of $32.8 million, $325.8 million in available consolidated lines of credit, 2.1 million original issue shares of

second half of 2025 (see Securities), and a debt-to-capital ratio of 35 percent.

Barn projects, and timing of recovery under Minnesota Power’s fuel adjustment clause. Cash provided by operating activities in 
2023 also increased due to the timing of recovery under Minnesota Power’s fuel adjustment clause.
Investing Activities. Cash used in investing activities was higher in 2024 compared to 2023 reflecting more  payments for 
additions to property, plant  and equipment  compared to 2023, partially offset  by state  cash grants received for our HVDC 
Transmission System Project in 2024. (See Outlook.)
Cash used in investing activities was lower in 2023 compared to 2022 reflecting cash payments for the  acquisition of New 
Energy in 2022. This decrease  was partially offset  by more  payments for additions to property, plant  and equipment  in 2023 
compared to 2022.
Financing Activities. Cash used in financing activities was lower in 2024 compared to 2023 reflecting higher proceeds from the 
issuance of long-term debt compared in 2024, partially offset by higher repayments of long-term debt in 2024.
Cash used in financing activities in 2023 reflected lower proceeds from the issuance of common stock and the issuance of long-
term debt, and lower proceeds from the issuance of non-controlling interest in subsidiaries compared to 2022.

Liquidity and Capital Resources(Continued)
Working Capital . Additional working capital, if and when needed, generally is provided by consolidated bank lines of credit 
and the  issuance  of securities, including long-term  debt, common stock and commercial  paper. As of December 31, 2024, we 
had consolidated bank lines of credit  aggregating $362.0 million ($423.1 million as of December 31, 2023), most  of which 
expire  in January 2027. We  had $16.2 million outstanding in standby letters of credit  and $20.0 million outstanding draws 
under our lines of credit  as of December 31, 2024 ($19.4 million in standby letters of credit  and $34.1 million outstanding 
draws as of December 31, 2023). We also have other credit facility agreements in place that provide the ability to issue up to 
$180.0 million in standby letters of credit. As of December 31, 2024, we had $118.4 million outstanding in standby letters of 
credit under these agreements.
In addition, as of December 31, 2024, we  had 2.4 million original  issue  shares of our common stock available  for issuance 
through Invest  Direct  and 2.1 million original  issue  shares of common stock available  for issuance  through a  distribution 
agreement with Lampert Capital Markets. (See Securities.) The amount and timing of future sales of our securities will depend 
upon market conditions and our specific needs.
Securities. The Merger Agreement also provides that ALLETE may notify Alloy Parent of our intent to raise equity capital of 
up to a total of $300 million in the second half of 2025, subject to certain parameters. If Alloy Parent declines to participate in 
the equity capital  raises or fails to provide  timely notice  with respect  thereto, ALLETE  will have  the right  to issue  ALLETE 
common stock in the public markets for an amount equal to any unfunded amounts under such equity capital raises up to certain 
limits. (See Note 15. Agreement and Plan of Merger.)
We entered into a  distribution agreement  with Lampert  Capital  Markets, in 2008, as amended most  recently in 2020, with 
respect to the issuance and sale of up to an aggregate of 13.6 million shares of our common stock, without par value, of which 
2.1 million shares remain available for issuance as of December 31, 2024. For the year ended December 31, 2024, no shares of 
common stock were issued under this agreement (none in 2023; none in 2022). 
During the year ended December 31, 2024, we issued 0.3 million shares of common stock through Invest Direct, the Employee 
Stock Purchase  Plan and the  Retirement  Savings and Stock Ownership Plan, resulting in net  proceeds of $12.9 million 
(0.3 million shares for net proceeds of $14.9 million in 2023; 0.3 million shares for net proceeds of $16.2 million in 2022). See 
Note 10. Common Stock and Earnings Per Share for additional detail regarding ALLETE’s equity securities.
Financial Covenants. See Note 8. Short-Term and Long-Term Debt for information regarding our financial covenants.
Pension and Other  Postretirement Benefit Plans. Management  considers various factors when making funding decisions, 
such as regulatory requirements, actuarially determined minimum contribution requirements and contributions required to avoid 
benefit restrictions for the defined benefit pension plans. For the year ended December 31, 2024, we made $25.0 million in cash 
contributions to the  defined benefit  pension plans. On January 15, 2025, we  contributed $19.1 million in cash to the  defined 
benefit pension plans, and do not expect to make additional cash contributions to the defined benefit pension plans in 2025. We 
do not  expect  to make  any contributions to the  defined benefit  postretirement  health and life  plans in 2025. (See  Note  10. 
Common Stock and Earnings Per Share and Note 12. Pension and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans.)
Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements. Off-balance sheet arrangements are discussed in Note 9. Commitments, Guarantees and 
Contingencies.
Contractual Obligations and Commercial Commitments. ALLETE has contractual obligations and other commitments that 
will need to be funded in the future, in addition to its capital expenditure programs. Material contractual obligations and other 
commitments are as follows:
Long-Term Debt.  ALLETE  has material  long-term  debt obligations, including long-term  debt due within one  year. These 
obligations include the principal amount of bonds, notes and loans which are recorded on the Consolidated Balance Sheet, plus 
interest. (See Note 8. Short-Term and Long -Term Debt.)
80
OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
MP Exhibit __ (CBA) Rebuttal Schedule 1 
Page 80 of 82
Liquidity and Capital Resources (Continued)
Contractual Obligations and Commercial Commitments (Continued)
Pension and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans. Pension and other postretirement benefit plan obligations include the current 
estimate of future benefit payments. Pension contributions are dependent on several factors including realized asset 
performance, future discount rate and other actuarial assumptions, Internal Revenue Service and other regulatory requirements, 
and contributions required to avoid benefit restrictions for the pension plans. Funding for the other postretirement benefit plans 
is impacted by realized asset performance, future discount rate and other actuarial assumptions, and utility regulatory 
requirements. Our obligations are estimates and will change based on actual market performance, changes in interest rates and 
any changes in governmental regulations. (See Note 12. Pension and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans.)
Operating and Finance Lease Obligations. ALLETE has certain operating and finance lease obligations for the minimum 
payments required under various lease agreements which are recorded on the Consolidated Balance Sheet. (See Note 1. 
Operations and Significant Accounting Policies.)  
Easement Obligations. ALLETE has easement obligations for the minimum payments required under our land easement 
agreements at our wind energy facilities. (See Note 9. Commitments, Guarantees and Contingencies.)
PPA Obligations. PPA obligations represent our Square Butte, Manitoba Hydro and other PPAs. (See Note 9. Commitments, 
Guarantees and Contingencies.)
Other Purchase Obligations. ALLETE has other purchase obligations covering our minimum purchase commitments under 
coal supply and rail contracts, and long-term service agreements for wind energy facilities. (See Note 9. Commitments, 
Guarantees and Contingencies.)
Credit Ratings. Access to reasonably priced capital markets is dependent in part on credit and ratings. Our securities have been 
rated by S&P and by Moody’s. Rating agencies use both quantitative and qualitative measures in determining a company’s 
credit rating. These measures include business risk, liquidity risk, competitive position, capital mix, financial condition, 
predictability of cash flows, management strength and future direction. Some of the quantitative measures can be analyzed 
through a few key financial ratios, while the qualitative ones are more subjective. Our current credit ratings are listed in the 
following table:
Credit Ratings S&P (a) Moody’s
Issuer Credit Rating BBB Baa1
Commercial Paper A-2 P-2
First Mortgage Bonds (b) A2
(a) On May 7, 2024, S&P Global Ratings revised its outlook on ALLETE to negative from stable and affirmed all of its ratings on ALLETE.
S&P Global Ratings cited the possibility for higher leverage and weaker financial measures because of the Merger as its rationale for
issuing the negative outlook.
(b) Not rated by S&P.
The disclosure of these credit ratings is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold our securities. Ratings are subject to revision 
or withdrawal  at any time by the  assigning  rating  organization.  Each  rating  should  be evaluated  independently  of any  other 
rating. 
Common Stock  Dividends. ALLETE  is committed  to providing  a competitive  dividend  to its  shareholders  while  at the same 
time funding its growth. ALLETE’s long-term objective is to maintain a dividend payout ratio similar to our peers and provide 
for future dividend increases. Our targeted payout range is between 60 percent and 70 percent. In 2024, we paid out 91 percent 
(63 percent in 2023; 77 percent in 2022) of our per share earnings in dividends. On January 30, 2025, our Board of Directors 
declared a dividend of $0.73 per share, which is payable on March 1, 2025, to shareholders of record at the close of business on 
February 14, 2025.
Under  the Merger  Agreement,  the Company  has agreed  not to declare  or pay  dividends  except  for quarterly  cash dividends 
payable  by us in  respect  of shares  of our common  stock  on a schedule  consistent  with our past  practices  in an amount  not to 
exceed  5 percent  per share  more  than the dividend  payable  during  the prior  12-month  period,  subject  to certain  other 
exceptions. (See Note 15. Agreement and Plan of Merger).

Q. How do you respond to Witness Keyes’ concern about the future security of 5 
benefits?  6 
A. Witness Keyes ’ statement assumes that benefits for bargaining employees can just be 7 
discontinued, but this is not the case. In fact, there are several protections in place for 8 
these benefits .  9 
 10 
 For example, pension -eligible bargaining unit employees have pension plan benefits 11 
under the qualified ALLETE and Affiliated Companies Pension Plan B or ALLETE and 12 
Affiliated Companies Pension Plan C  (collectively the “Pension Plans” ). These 13 
qualified pension plans meet the requirements  set by the I nternal Revenue Code  (“IRC ”) 14 
and the Employee  Retirement Income Security  Act (“ERISA”). Under the anti -cutback 15 
rules of Section 411(d)(6) of the I RC, benefits under a qualified pension plan cannot be 16 
reduced because these rules are designed to protect participants ’ accrued benefits. 17 
Specifically, the anti -cutback rules prevent any plan amendment from decreasing the 18 
benefits a participant  has already  accrued, which also includes  early retirement benefits, 19 
retirement -type subsidies, or other optional forms of benefits . These requirements are 20 
in place for all participants, regardless of if they are currently active, terminated, or in 21 
payout status.  22 
 23 
Additionally , the Company has existing agreements  relate d to required funding levels 24 
for the Pension Plans  and the Other Post -Employment Benefit  (“OPEB”).  25 
 26 
In a 2015  Letter of Understanding  between the Company and IBEW Local 31 , the 27 
Company agree d to fund the Pension Plan s at 80  percent  or higher (based on the adjusted 28 
funding target attainment percentage ). Also, both ERISA and the Pension Protection 29 
Act (and subsequent regulations) provide specific funding requirements that plan 30 
sponsors must annually meet , and ALLETE has and will continue to meet these 31

Krollman Rebuttal  requirements. The funding requirements take into account retirees in payout status, 1 
terminated employees, and active employees, meaning that the trusts do not just cover 2 
benefits for participants already in payout status.  3 
 4 
In 2023 , the Company and IBEW Local 31 agreed to not decrease the Voluntary 5 
Employees’ Beneficiary Association  (“VEBA”) trusts below 100  percent  of the 6 
calculated OPEB  liability.  The OPEB benefits covered by the VEBA are post -retirement 7 
health and retiree life insurance. Similar to the pensio n funding, to determine the 8 
appropriate amount to fund, the actuaries are required to factor in employees eligible 9 
for this benefit, not just participants in payout status.  10 
 11 
Actuaries are required to follow strict guidelines under the Actuarial Standards of 12 
Practice to calculate liabilities and funding requirements, and work with the Company 13 
to ensure  the plans remain solvent and capable of meeting their obligations to all 14 
participants.  15 
 16 
The Company’s commitment to funding these plans at specific levels (e.g., 80  percent  17 
for the Pension Plans  and 100  percent  for the VEBA trusts) demonstrates a proactive 18 
approach to ma intaining the financial security of these benefits.  19 
 20 
The Company feels that the protections for bargaining employee  post-employment 21 
benefits are robust and  multifaceted, encompassing federal legal requirements, 22 
collective bargaining agreements,  actuarial oversight, and  Company -specific 23 
commitments. These safeguards ensure that the benefits earned by bargaining 24 
employees are secure and cannot be unilaterally discontinued.  25

Bram Rebuttal  I. INTRODUCTION AND QUALIFICATIONS  1 
Q. Please state your name  and employer . 2 
A. My name is Jonathan Bram and I am a founding partner of Global Infrastructure 3 
Partners, which is the trading name for Global Infrastructure Management, LLC along 4 
with related funds (collectively “GIP”).   5 
 6 
Q. Did you provide Direct Testimony in this proceeding?  7 
A. Yes. 8 
 9 
Q. Can you summarize your Direct Testimony in this proceeding?  10 
A. In my Direct Testimony I  provide d information about GIP and the GIP -managed funds 11 
that, if the acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. by GIP and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 12 
(“CPP Investments”) (the “Acquisition”) is approved, will own a portion of ALLETE, Inc. , 13 
which includes the public utility, Minnesota Power.1 I also described why the Acquisition 14 
is consistent with the public interest , specifically how it will benefit Minnesota Power 15 
and its customers and how potential risks or concerns of the Acquisition will be avoided 16 
or addressed .  17

obligation to serve customers in return for a fair opportunity to earn a reasonable return 11 
on prudent investments, all of which are governed and overseen by the applicable 12 
regulatory commission. Regulation  benefits both the public and investors . For investors, 13 
the regulatory compact  is a positive feature of utility operations because it helps provide 14 
stability and ensure long -term, stable returns —both valuable characteristics in an 15 
investment that allow GIP to construct a diversified portfolio as I discussed earlier. That 16 
benefit comes with certain regulatory requirements  as well, and those regulatory 17 
requirements, which are determined and enforced by applicable regulatory agencies like 18 
the Commission, help ensure the public is sufficiently protected from any adverse 19 
effects of private ownership of utilities.   20

be insufficient.37 29

above that is a “windfall” that the owner does not deserve. They could not earn a profit 20

public interest.   23

investments: to earn a return from the investment. This is no different than ALLETE’s 29

beginning in its next rate case  and continuing so long as the Partners own 4 
Alloy . 5 
• The Partners will not charge fees for any business management or consulting 6 
services provided to ALLETE or Minnesota Power.  7 
• ALLETE’s capital structure will be maintained within the range approved 8 
by the Commission in the annual capital structure filing, and Minnesota 9 
Power will continue its efforts to manage its capital structure to the level 10 
approved in its most recent Minnesota rate case.   For example, ALLETE will 11 
not make any dividend or distribution that would cause the actual equity ratio 12 
of ALLETE to be outside the range approved by the Commission in the 13 
annual capital structure filing.  So long as Minnesota Power and ALLETE 14 
remain the same entity, the Company will continue to make its annual capital 15 
structure filings with the Commission.  16 
• For as long as Minnesota Power is owned by the Partners, Minnesota Power 17 
will not request rate recovery of board compensation or expenses for any 18 
board member not independent from the Partners.  19 
• Minnesota Power will not seek rate recovery of flotation costs beginning  20 
with its next rate case  and continuing for so long as the Partners own Alloy . 21 
• The Company will not attempt to recover Acquisition costs from utility 22 
customers.  23 
• The Company will not attempt to recover transition costs related to the 24 
Acquisition from utility customers, except to the extent of savings.  25 
• The Company will have the burden to prove in its next rate case that no 26 
transaction costs, nor the costs identified in the Ratemaking section of this 27 
proposal for exclusion from future rate cases, are included in the cost of 28 
service to be recovered from customers.  29 
• If Minnesota Power’s cost of debt increases above current levels within three 30 
years following the close of the Acquisition, Minnesota ratepayers will be 31 
held harmless from any rate impact unless Minnesota Power can 32 
demonstrate that its increased cost of debt was not caused by the Acquisition.  33 
• The Company commits to not make any dividend or distributions unless at 34 
least one senior unsecured credit rating is investment grade or above.  35 
• The Partners commit that the governance of ALLETE will be handled 36 
consistent with the following concepts:  37 
o The day -to-day operations of Minnesota Power will be handled by the 38 
Minnesota Power senior management team.  39 
o The members of the ALLETE board will be selected by the Partners 40 
based on their experience in relevant industries.  41 
o 13 total board members, with each investor having the right to appoint 42 
one director to the board for every 10 percent ownership of ALLETE, 43 
Inc. held indirectly through Alloy Parent.  44 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 60 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Bram Rebuttal  • The purpose of this commitment is to clarify that the ALLETE board has 1 
authority to make decisions for the Company, in alignment with the current 2 
operation of the Company.  3 
• The chief executive officer (CEO) of ALLETE will be a voting  member of 4 
the post -Acquisition ALLETE board of directors.  5 
• In addition to the ALLETE CEO, the ALLETE board will include two 6 
independent members, with one member from Minnesota and one member 7 
from Wisconsin, each of whom will be a voting member.   8 
• The ALLETE CEO’s board seat will not count as the director from the State 9 
of Minnesota or State of Wisconsin on the post -acquisition Board of 10 
Directors.  11 
• ALLETE  will use commercially reasonable efforts to remain rated by at least 12 
two credit rating agencies.  13 
• Minnesota Power will continue to provide ALLETE credit rating reports to 14 
the Commission within 30 days of receipt of the reports from the rating 15 
agencies.  16 
• A new tax -sharing agreement will be established between ALLETE and 17 
Alloy Parent. Commission approval is required for the Company to sign the 18 
agreement.  19 
• Minnesota Power will require all suppliers, and any industrial customers 20 
with contracted rates,  to identify annually whether they are more than 5% 21 
owned by CPPIB, GIP, or Blackrock. Minnesota Power will list those 22 
entities in the annual affiliated interest report.  23 
• Minnesota Power will identify any contracts over $1 million with an entity 24 
identified pursuant to the commitment above and notify the Commission 25 
within 30 days of the execution of each contract not already disclosed to the 26 
Commission, with a certification that the contract was negotiated  at arm ’s 27 
length.  28 
• Minnesota Power will be prohibited from loaning funds to or borrowing 29 
funds from its post -Acquisition parent or other upstream entities.   30 
• Alloy Parent will not use utility assets to guarantee Alloy Parent debt.  31 
 32 
XI. CONCLUSION  33 
Q. Please summarize the conclusions of your Rebuttal Testimony.  34 
A. The Company’s and Partners’ Rebuttal Testimony confirms both the severe risks to 35 
ALLETE of attempting to obtain the equity needed for the unprecedented increase to its 36 
capital expenditures needed to meet the Minnesota Carbon Free Standard and other 37 
needs of Minnesota Power. The patient equity from the Partners that will be made 38 
available as a result of the Acquisition is the solution to that need. The Partners will be 39 
excellent partners for ALLETE as their track records show and their commitments 40 
confirm, and the Company and ALLETE will continue to engage in finding constructive 41 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 61 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Bram Rebuttal  solutions. As a result, the Acquisition is clearly in the public interest and the 1 
Commission should approve the Acquisition.  2 
Q. Does this complete your testimony?  3 
A. Yes. 4

 1   OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
Alley Rebuttal  I. INTRODUCTION AND SUMMARY  1 
Q. Please state your name and employer.  2 
A. My name is Andrew Alley and I am Managing Director, Head of Infrastructure, North 3 
America & Australasia at Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”).  4 
 5 
Q. Did you prepare Direct Testimony in this proceeding?  6 
A. Yes. I filed Direct Testimony on behalf of CPP Investments  and in support of the proposed 7 
acquisition of ALLETE , Inc.  (the “Acquisition”) by CPP Investments and funds managed 8 
by Global Infrastructure Management, LLC and related  funds (“GIP ” and together with 9 
CPP Investments “the Partners” ).1 10 
  11 
Q. Have you had a chance to review the Direct Testimony filed by Parties and, if so, what 12 
is your reaction?  13 
A. Yes, I have reviewed the Direct Testimony filed by Parties ,2 and I will respond to 14 
Department of Commerce (“DOC”) Witness Addonizio, DOC Witness Vavro, Office of 15 
Attorney General (“OAG”) Witness Lebens, CURE Witness Baker, CURE Witness Ellis, 16 
Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”) Witness Walters and Sierra Club (“Sierra”) Witness 17 
Lane.  Some  Parties appear to not understand the need for, and purpose of, the Acquisition, 18 
and as a result, they assert that the Commission should deny approval of the Acquisition 19 
as not in the public interest. Before I address any specific arguments made by Parties , I 20 
want to respond to this overarching point and highlight a few items.  21 
 22 
Q. What is the fundamental purpose of the Acquisition?  23 
A. ALLETE decided that it needed to be acquired because it would not be able to access the 24 
capital it needs through public markets. Minnesota Power is required by law to source retail 25 
 
1 Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout my Testimony and the Petition, 
“Minnesota Power” refers to this regulated utility. Unless otherwise specifically defined, references to “ALLETE” 
indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota Power and all regulated and non -regulate d 
subsidiaries. “The Company” is a more general reference to ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.  
2 The following entities filed testimony in this proceeding: the Minnesota Department of Commerce, Office of the 
Minnesota Attorney General, Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, CURE, IBEW Local 31, Laborers International 
Union of North America, Large Power Intervenors, and Sierra Club (each a “ Party ” and collectively, the “ Parties ”). 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 2 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
 sales with 100 percent carbon -free energy by 2040 . Minnesota Power also has received 1 
approval to begin construction of two transmission lines that will require investment of 2 
approximately $2 billion3 in capital, along with growing investments to maintain and 3 
modernize its distribution system. This work  will require substantial capital expenditures 4 
in the future —capital expenditures that far exceed the level that Minnesota Power has 5 
undertaken in the past . As explained in the Rebuttal Testimony of  Company Witness  Taran , 6 
the Company estimates that Minnesota Power will have roughly $1 billion in equity needs 7 
in the next five years alone , which is consistent with the Commission ’s recent approv al of 8 
multiple large, needed transmission line projects . Company Witness Taran further explains  9 
that the Company has been able to  access  certain quantities of equity  in the public markets 10 
in the past, but as Company Witness Taran and Company and Partner Witness 11 
Quackenbush explain, past success in the public equity market does not guarantee similar 12 
future results .   13 
 14 
Company and Partner Witness Quackenbush explain s that the Company’s three -year 15 
capital expenditure is accelerating from 24.8 percent historically to 78.9 percent on a 16 
projected basis. Moreover , Company Witness Taran provides that the Company’s equity 17 
need over the next five years is an unprecedent ed amount that represents almost the total 18 
amount of equity the Company has raised since becoming public nearly 75 years ago and 19 
would be incredibly ambitious  to raise through public markets. I t is almost certain that the 20 
Company will face significant challenges in the future to raise the amount of equity 21 
necessary to satisfy Minnesota ’s clean energy requirements as a public company. 22 
Additionally, even if the equity capital were available through the public market , the 23 
Company would have to go to market more frequently, which means it may not be able to 24 
avoid attempting to issue equity during significant market downturns or, as Company 25 
Witness Scissons notes,  large load cyclicality  to which Minnesota Power, in particular, is 26 
susceptible.   27 
 28 
 
3 Unless noted otherwise, all dollar figures are in USD.  
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 3 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
 Given that backdrop, ALLETE determined that it needed to explore its options for raising 1 
such extraordinary amounts of capital relative to its size. After examining several options 2 
described in its proxy statement, ALLETE  ultimately chose to pursue a potential sale 3 
transaction because it had determined  that an acquisition  of the Company by appropriate 4 
strategic investors was the best way for  Minnesota Power to meet its obligations under 5 
Minnesota law and to continue to meet the needs of its customers. After analyzing its 6 
options  and undertaking a robust and lengthy evaluation of potential partners , the Company 7 
chose to partner with CPP Investments and GIP in the Acquisition because it understood 8 
that the well-capitalized  Partners  were aligned with the Company’s values and were 9 
positioned to  help the Company meet its goals.  10 
 11 
Q. How well do Parties  characterize  the Partners?  12 
A. While some Parties  recognize the value the Partners can bring to the region and have 13 
brought to bear in other interactions , other  Party witnesses rely heavily on the mistaken 14 
assumption that CPP Investments and GIP may use potentially problematic  strategies, such 15 
as a short -run focus or an interest in depleting or redirecting utility assets  away from utility 16 
service .4 These concerns are misguided , generalized fears that are contrary the Partners’ 17 
approach to investments and the record . The Partners ’ reasons for investing  in ALLETE  18 
and Minnesota Power, and their long -term investment strategies , differ from private equity 19 
strategies that seek to extract economic value from the acquisition using short -term 20 
strategies that are not intended to leave the acquired company better off. This appears to 21 
be the type of invest ment strateg y that a number of  the Party  witnesses are concerned about , 22 
but this strategy is far different from that of the Partners  generally, and with respect to the 23 
Acquisition specifically . I will address these differences in my Rebuttal  Testimony . 24 
 25 
CPP Investments is a steward of the funds entrusted to it for investment for the benefit of  26 
over 22 million Canadian s. It has an investment -only mandate , as provided by the Canada 27 
 
4 See e.g. OAG -RUD Ex. __ (BPL) at 14  (“Lebens Direct ”) (enumerating the significant changes a private equity 
investor may make to change a business ’ cash flow ); CURE Ex. __ (JPB) at 5 -7 (“Baker Direct”).  
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 4 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
 Pension Plan Investment Board Act , and as such, focuses on the strategy of a company but 1 
does not manage the day-to-day operations of its investments.5 It employs a diversified 2 
investment strategy across numerous different sectors to build a balanced portfolio. The 3 
Acquisition was source d and sponsored  through CPP Investments’ infrastructure group, 4 
which generally focuses on  long-term, stable investments , tying back to its larger mandate . 5 
As explained in my Direct Testimony, an independent federal body monitors the long -term 6 
financial sustainability of CPP Investments, and in its most recent report reconfirmed  that 7 
CPP Investments is financially  sustainable for at least the next 75 years.  Simply put, o ur 8 
approach with respect to the Company is incompatible with assumptions and claims made 9 
by some Parties  about problematic investment strategies , and our track record, including 10 
in other  regulated  utility businesses, demonstrates that.  11 
 12 
Moreover, the CPP Investments infrastructure group  is not in the business of investing in 13 
a company just to extract value and let it flounder . Rather, the success of CPP Investments ’ 14 
strategy is predicated on increasing the market value of its investments  over the long term, 15 
as I will discuss more below . The Partners are interested in acquiring the Company because 16 
it is a strong performing regulated utility  with values and principles that align with the 17 
Partners; the Company  has substantial future capital needs and  the Partners are perfectly 18 
suited to help the Company satisfy its obligations to the Minnesota legislature, to the 19 
Commission, and to customers . 20 
 21 
In summary, CPP Investments’  mission, combined with the capital and expertise we can 22 
bring to the Company to help it achieve its goals, demonstrate why the Acquisition is in 23 
the public interest and should be approved.   24 
 25 
 
5 197 S.C. ch.40 (Can.) of 1997, available at https://laws -lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/C -8.3/.

 5 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
 Q. Have the Company and Partners made additional commitments to address certain 1 
Party  concerns?  2 
A. Yes. While I believe that the Company and Partners demonstrated in Direct Testimony 3 
why the Commission should approve the Acquisition, CPP Investments understands  that 4 
certain Parties  continue to have concerns. Consequently, the Company and the Partners 5 
have proposed  a substantial number of additional commitments in good faith to address 6 
those concerns, as explained herein and in the Rebuttal  Testimonies of the Company 7 
Witnesses and GIP Witness Bram.  These additional commitments further  demonstrate that 8 
the Partners will be reliable stewards , who intend to continue to work with stakeholders to 9 
reasonably address concerns,  and ultimately, that the Acquisition is in the public interest.  10 
 11 
Q. How is your Rebuttal Testimony  organized ? 12 
A. Section II of my Rebuttal Testimony presents and explains CPP Investments’ support for 13 
the Petitioners’ Commitments, including numerous  additional commitments or 14 
modifications of commitments already made by Petitioners to meet concerns raised by 15 
Parties  (the “Additional Commitments”) . Section III of my Rebuttal Testimony states CPP 16 
Investments’ positions regarding the main contested issues, including some issues where 17 
the Petitioners’ have provided additional commitments to address certain concerns raised.   18 
Section IV contains my conclusions.   19 
 20 
Q.  Do you respond to CUB Witness Scott Hempling  in your Rebuttal Testimony ? 21 
A.  No. Based on CUB’s Response to the Motion to Strike and Revoke Access, dated February 22 
25, 2025, I understand that CUB has withdrawn Scott Hempling’s pre -filed Direct 23 
Testimony and no longer plans to file further testimony from him. Because CUB has 24 
withdrawn that testimony, Minnesota Power and the Partners do not address it in rebuttal 25 
and instead focus on other witnesses’ testimony.  26 
 27

 6 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
 II. ADDITIONAL COMMITMENTS  1 
Q. What is the purpose of this section of your Rebuttal Testimony?  2 
A. The purpose of this section of my Rebuttal Testimony is to present and explain CPP 3 
Investment’s support for Additional Commitments that the Petitioners are making to 4 
resolve concerns expressed by the Department, the OAG, and other Parties . 5 
 6 
Q. Does the Rebuttal Testimony of Company Witness Jennifer  Cady include a list of all 7 
commitments by the Petitioners, including the additional commitments?  8 
A. Yes. That list of commitments is included at MP Ex. ___ (JJC), Rebuttal Schedule 1 to 9 
Company  Witness Cady’s Rebuttal Testimony.   10 
 11 
Q. Does CPP Investments support and affirm all those commitments?  12 
A. Yes. CPP Investments supports and affirms all the Petitioners’ commitments.  13 
 14 
Q. Do you have additional comments on some of the Petitioners’ commitments?  15 
A. Yes. I want to highlight several of the Petitioners’ commitments, including  (i) the Partners’ 16 
express commitment , through Alloy Parent,  to fund Minnesota Power’s five -year capital 17 
plan, (ii) certain capital structure and ring-fencing commitments that will ensure the 18 
protection of Minnesota Power, and (iii) certain commitments that demonstrate that the 19 
Partners are deeply invested in and value the community in Northern Minnesota . 20 
 21 
Q. What are your comments as to the Partners’ express commitment to fund Minnesota 22 
Power’s five -year capital plan?  23 
A. The primary purpose of the Acquisition i s to provide the Company with adequate access 24 
to capital to meet its requirements , as stated by Company Witness Taran . As discussed 25 
further herein, however, a number of Party witnesses , including Sierra Witness Lane, LPI 26 
Witness Walters, DOC Witness Vavro , and DOC Witness Addonizio,  express concerns 27 
about whether the Partners will actually improve the Company’s access to equity capital  28 
and some suggest that the Company’s access to equity capital will be worse following the 29 
Acquisition . To address this, the Partners expressly  commit , through Alloy Parent,  to 30 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 7 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
 providing Minnesota Power sufficient equity financing so that it can achieve its five -year 1 
capital plan. These  Party  witnesses assert that the Company has been able to access 2 
sufficient capital through the public markets as a publicly -traded company in the past ; 3 
therefore it will be able to do so in the future  and the Partners are not actually providing 4 
any commitment to provide capital.6 As Company Witness Taran and Company and 5 
Partners Witness Quackenbush explain, the Company has substantial future capital needs 6 
that far outpace  prior capital needs, and they estimate that at least $1 billion is needed in 7 
the next five years , which is nearly equivalent to the total amount of equity the Company 8 
has raised since becoming public nearly 75 years ago . There is considerable risk with 9 
relying on the public markets to raise the needed capital going forward. The Partners, on 10 
the other hand, are committing to provide certainty regarding the primary benefit of the 11 
Acquisition —access to equity capital . The Company would not be able to obtain any such 12 
commitment in the public market. This commitment is subject to the Commission’s 13 
determinations regarding rate recovery, revenue allocation and resource decisions, which 14 
provide necessary protections to customers  and flexibility if Minnesota Power’s needs 15 
change . 16 
  17 
Q. Does that mean you will not provide equity capital after five years?  18 
A. No. The Partners  intend  to provide sufficient equity capital to Minnesota Power for the 19 
long-term, and for the entire duration of our ownership. The reason we are pursuing the 20 
Acquisition is because we  intend to  build value within the Company , in the best interest of 21 
Minnesota Power, its customers , and the northern Minnesota community . We are 22 
commit ting, through Alloy Parent,  that we will provide equity capital for Minnesota Power 23 
to achieve its five -year capital plan to address Party concerns and to provide certainty about 24 
funding at the outset.  As discussed further herein, this commitment does not represent a 25 
ceiling on the level of the Partners’ funding, but demonstrates that we are committed to the 26 
success of Minnesota Power , including Minnesota Power’s ability to  reach its 2040 27 
decarbonization requirements . 28 
 
6 See e.g. , SIERRA Ex. __ (CL) at 11 (“Lane Direct”) ; DOC Ex. __ (CMA) at 20 (“Addonizio Direct”).   
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 8 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
  1 
Q. What are your comments as to capital structure measures and ring-fencing  2 
protections?  3 
A. Certain Party witnesses, including DOC Witnesses Addonizio and Vavro, raise concerns 4 
about whether the financial health of Minnesota Power will be adequately protected. As 5 
explained in my Direct Testimony and the Direct Testimony of Company and Partners 6 
Witness Lapson, the Partners are committing  to numerous ring -fencing measures to protect 7 
the health of Minnesota Power , including  an additional commitment  that the Company will 8 
not pay any dividends  unless at least one senior unsecured credit rating is investment grade 9 
or above. Furthermore, we commit that for three years following the Acquisition, if 10 
Minnesota Power’s cost of debt increases above current levels as a result of the Acquisition, 11 
Minnesota customers will be held harmless. I also want to clarify that Minnesota Power 12 
assets will not be used to guarantee any debt at the Alloy Parent level and Minnesota Power 13 
will be prohibited from loaning funds to or borrowing  funds from  Alloy Parent  or other 14 
upstream entities . The Partners are committed to safeguarding the financial health of 15 
Minnesota Power  and ensuring that this Acquisition does not directly result in any rate 16 
impacts for customers . 17 
 18 
Q. What are your comments as to Partner commitments that demonstrate you are 19 
committed to the community in Northern Minnesota ? 20 
A. As I stated in my Direct Testimony, we are pursuing the Acquisition in part because our 21 
core principles align with those of the Company, and we are committed to the Company, 22 
its employees and the community. Some Party witnesses, including DOC witness Vavro, 23 
question  that commitment. To demonstrate how seriously we take these principles , 24 
however , the Partners are making certain c ommitments to maintain the status quo, as well 25 
as substantial additional commitments. For example, so long as Minnesota Power is owned 26 
by the Partners: (i) it will be headquartered in Duluth, Minnesota; (ii) there will be no 27 
proposed reduction in Minnesota Power’s currently designed affordability program budget 28 
or program eligibility process; and (iii) the Company’s contributions to the Minnesota 29 
Power Foundation will not be reduced.  30 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 9 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
  1 
Q. Are there any additional commitments the Partners are undertaking that will benefit 2 
Minnesota Power’s customers?  3 
A.   On top of maintaining the status quo,  as discussed in more detail by  Witness Cady,  the 4 
Partners have agreed, in partnership with Minnesota Power and the EnergyCENTS 5 
Coalition, to significantly reduce arrearages of Minnesota Power’s residential customers , 6 
which are estimated to be approximately $3.5 million , and reflects a meaningful reset for 7 
the most economically challenged residential customers . This commitment was developed 8 
after careful consultation with the EnergyCENTS Coalition about the needs of Minnesota 9 
Power’s low -income customers, and it is a reflection of the Partners’ intention to engage 10 
with and support the community in northern Minnesota. The Partners are able to provide 11 
this commitment as an additional benefit of the Acquisition, which public market investors 12 
would not be able to do.  13 
 14 
Additionally , we are enabling Minnesota Power to work with IBEW Local 31 to develop a 15 
joint proposal to extend existing union contracts for two years and implement a first -ever 16 
Neutrality Agreement between the Company and IBEW Local 31. We  recognize that 17 
Minnesota Power’s success as a company, and therefore the success of CPP Investments’ 18 
investment in ALLETE, is tethered to the health of the community Minnesota Power serves 19 
as a regulated utility. We are deeply committed to Minnesota Power and the surrounding 20 
community, as demonstrated through these benefits.    21 
 22 
III. DISPUTED ISSUES  23 
A. Partners’ Long -Term  Approach to Investments  24 
Q. What is the purpose of this section of your Rebuttal T estimony?   25 
A.  This section of my Rebuttal T estimony  will reiterate and further explain  CPP Investments’ 26 
investment strategy , as well as address the concerns raised by the Parties  regarding whether 27 
CPP Investments ’ investment strategy  is consistent with their views of a stereotypical 28 
private equity firm. As explained further below, those criticisms are not applicable here, 29 
and the Partners’ have made a number of commitments to address the Parties ’ concerns.  30 
PUBLIC DOCUMENT - HIGHLY CONFIDENTIAL TRADE SECRET INFORMATION HAS BEEN EXCISED
 
 10 
 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339  
 MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 Alley Rebuttal  
  1 
Q. Did some Parties  raise concerns based on their view of a stereo typical  private equity 2 
firm’s investment strategy ?   3 
A. Yes. Witness Addonizio and Witness Lebens described the characteristics of some private 4 
equity investors as being focused on seeking higher returns  or impos ing radical changes on 5 
acquired companies.7 The witnesses appeared to assume or fear that the Partners would act 6 
in the same manner. But t hese arguments are based on unfounded assumptions about the 7 
Partners , as I will discuss more below . The information that I have provided about CPP 8 
Investments  in my Direct and Rebuttal Testimonies  and that Witness Bram has provided 9 
about GIP in his Testimon ies demonstrate that the Partners are not stereotypical  private 10 
equity firms . I will further explore this conclusion and provide examples to support it in 11 
this Rebuttal Testimony, and  I note that it  is further supported by the extensive 12 
commitments to which the Partners have agreed.  13 
 14 
Q.  Does Witness Addonizio suggest that the Partners may use an approach commonly 15 
taken by private equity firms to enhance their equity returns?  16 
A. Yes. Witness Addonizio suggests that the Partners, despite their stated intention not to do 17 
so, could use financial, governance, and engineering strategies commonly used by private 18 
equity firms to increase equity returns.8 19 
 20 
Q. Should  the Commission be concerned about that here?  21 
A. No. As I explained in my Direct Testimony, and my Rebuttal Testimony above, CPP 22 
Investments is not a typical private equity investor , nor is it a fund manager that charges 23 
high fees to drive up its return .9 We do not have a set fund life, and as the investment 24 
manager for the Canada Pension Plan (“CPP”) whose objective is to manage amounts 25 
transferred to it in the best interest of CPP contributors and beneficiaries, our investment 26 
strategy is not driven by quarterly results, but rather a focus on increasing the long -run 27 
 
7 Addonizio Direct at 53, 58-60; Lebens Direct at 13 -14. 
8 Addonizio Direct at 64-70. 
9 MP Ex. __ (AA) at 6 -7 (“Alley Direct”) .

 OAH Docket No. 25 -2500 -40339

Q. How does CPP Investments measure the value of its investments ?  10 
A. It’s important to understand how CPP Investments evaluates these types of investments 11 
from an internal accounting perspective. While it is true that a classic return on investment 12 
happens when you sell a company, that is not the exclusive , or even primary,  way that CPP 13 
Investments measures its return. Rather, it evaluates its investments on an annual basis 14 
using mark -to-market accounting: the value of the investment corresponds to its current 15 
market value.   16 
 17 
Thus, an investment increasing the value in the short term is not necessarily related to a 18 
desire to exit the investment at any given time . It simply reflects a desire to make the 19 
company more valuable through the necessary investments so that increase in value is 20 
reflected in our accounting and ongoing evaluation of our investment .  21

 Q. Does access to sufficient equity capital necessarily  result from sufficient ratemaking 1 
decisions?  2 
A. No. Sufficient ratemaking decisions by the Commission do not mean  that the Company 3 
will necessarily have sufficient access to equity capital through the public markets.  4 
Although reasonable ratemaking can be supportive of access to equity capital, allowing the 5 
Company to earn a fair and reasonable  return on capital expenditures by no means 6 
guarantees that the Company will have or be able to obtain the equity capital necessary to 7 
make initial investments. Furthermore, it does not guarantee access to equity capital o n 8 
favorable terms in public capital markets , particularly when the Company will need to 9 
make serial issuances to address its substantial future capital needs .   10 
 11 
 The Partners, on the other hand, can provide “patient” capital, meaning we are in a position 12 
to delay or even forgo dividends, which allows the Company to retain earnings and increase 13 
equity on its balance sheet. As Company and Partners Witness Quackenbush explains, 14 
private equity infusions in the form of retained earnings are significantly less costly and 15 
more flexible than equity available through the public markets. In fact, he illustrates that 16 
when utility companies that are public have cut dividends in the past, the overwhelming 17 
reaction has to been to punish the stock price, thereby making it even more challenging to 18 
access capital.  19 
 20

Company. But some Parties  seem to assume the opposite —that the Company can meet all 25

 Q. Please explain the flaws in opposition to a return on investment that arises from 1 
acquisition of a utility.  2 
A. ALLETE’s status as a public company necessarily involves shareholders gaining returns 3 
in the form of dividends and, potentially, returns from profitable sales of their shares in the 4 
public market. That is already happening now, for existing shareholders. The Acquisition 5 
will not change the foundational principle that owners of a business expect a return on their 6 
investments. But it will change the nature of that expectation from the more volatile, short - 7 
run focus on dividends and quarterly earnings of shareholders in a public company to the 8 
more stable, long -run focus of private investors like the Partners.  9 
 10 
 Moreover, allowing investors who dedicate their capital to have an opportunity  to earn  a 11 
reasonable return on investment benefits customers, is necessarily in the public interest and 12 
indeed is the core foundation of  the regulatory compact. In this case, allowing a return on 13 
investment incentivizes investment in Minnesota regulated utilities, which allows those 14 
utilities to access the capital they need to meet Minnesota’s Carbon  Free Standard and other 15 
public policy goals.     16 
 17 
Q. How does this relate to the Acquisition?  18 
A. That is exactly what the petitioners seek to achieve with this Acquisition . The Acquisition’s 19 
primary benefit is to facilitate Minnesota Power’s ability to meet the Minnesota Carbon 20 
Free Standard (using both the Partners’ financing and expertise). The Partners have a 21 
greater tolerance for delay in achieving a return as compared to shareholders of a public 22 
company, as evidenced by the Partners’ commitment that Minnesota Power’s 5 -year capital 23 
plan will be funded  regardless of intervening returns  and dividends . The Partners also have 24 
extensive experience in achieving large -scale infrastructure investment, with focused 25 
experience  and skill in investment in  renewable energy and carbon reduction, as evidenced 26 
by CPP Investments’ successful investment in Puget  discussed previously. As a result, the 27 
Acquisition will further empower Minnesota Power to undertake the transformation to  be 28 
carbon free .   29

 Q. What is your response to those assertion s? 1 
A. I want to provide context regarding what the presentation relied on by DOC Witness 2 
Addonizio and CURE Witness  Baker is, and what it is not. Any time CPP Investments 3 
considers making an investment, it is required to obtain internal approval s. In order to 4

that analyzes the potential  investment in detail, including numerous different scenarios to 6 
consider a range of possible outcomes.  These different scenarios necessarily include 7 
different periods in which CPP Investments may exit  an investment, as well as scenarios 8 
in which CPP Investments holds an investment in perpetuity. This analysis is conducted at 9 
a single point in time and is based on the best information that CPP Investments has as of 10 
that time. It is  not meant to accurately predict the outcome of any given investment. It is 11 
simply a tool that CPP Investments , and other similar investors, use to evaluate a potential 12 
investment and to get approval to move forward  with the understanding that any of the 13 
possible outcomes analyzed may or may not come to fruition.  14

Q. Will the Partners retain consent rights over any decisions regarding the Company?  10

specific actions. This structure ensures shared control of decision making, adding stability 27 
to the overall governance. These consent rights give the Partners the ability to say yes, or 28 
no, over a specific action —they do not give the Partners the ability to impose a specific 29 
action , or even modify it.   30

 INTRODUCTION  1 
Q. What is your name, position, and business address ? 2 
A.  My name is Ann E. Bulkley. I am a Principal at The Brattle Group (“Brattle”).  My business 3 
address is One Beacon Street, Suite 2600, Boston, Massachusetts 02108.  4 
 5 
Q. On whose behalf are you submitting this Rebuttal Testimony?  6 
A.  I am submitting this Rebuttal Testimony before the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 7 
(“Commission”) on behalf of ALLETE, Inc. (“ALLETE”), d/b/a Minnesota Power.  8 
 9 
 PURPOSE AND OVERVIEW OF DIRECT TESTIMONY  10 
Q. Please describe the purpose of your Direct Testimony . 11 
A.  The purpose of my Rebuttal  Testimony is to respond to the Direct Testimony of Craig  12 
Addonizio (“Addonizio Direct Testimony”) on behalf of the Minnesota Department of 13 
Commerce, Division of Energy Resources (“DOC” or “Department”) , Brian Lebens 14 
(“Lebens Direct Testimony”) on behalf of the Office of Attorney General (“OAG”), 15 
Courtney Lane (“Lane  Direct Testimony”) on behalf of the Sierra Club (“Sierra”) , Douglas 16 
Jester (“Jester Direct Testimony”) on behalf of OAG,  and Mark Ellis (“Ellis Direct 17 
Testimony”) on behalf of CURE .  18 
 19 
Q.  How is your Rebuttal Testimony  organized?  20 
A. My Rebuttal Testimony  addresses the following issues: 1) Intervenor questions regarding 21 
whether there would be c hanges in the cost of equity (“COE”)  as a result of the Acquisition , 22 
2) potential risk  associated with financing the ongoing operations of ALLETE , and 3) 23 
single issue ratemaking.  24

Bulkley Rebuttal   1 
 CHANGES IN THE WEIGHTED AVERAGE COST OF CAPITAL  RESULTING 2 
FROM THE ACQUISITION  3 
Q. Please summarize the positions of the intervenor and the other party witnesses 4 
regarding concerns about potential changes in Minnesota  Power’s the cost of capital 5 
and ROE  as a result of the acquisition.  6 
A.  Department wit ness Addonizio suggests that in an attempt to increase returns , private 7 
equity investors manage  financial structure to increase leverage , which may raise the cost 8 
of capital for Minnesota Power .1 Sierra Club  witness  Lane also suggests that the acquisition 9 
of ALLETE is likely to create greater pressure from the private equity owners  that will 10 
result in greater capital investment and increased return on equity (“ ROE ”) requests.2 11 
Finally, Sierra Club  witness Jester reviews the transaction acquiring Upper Peninsula 12 
Power Company (“ UPPCO ”) and suggests that the company petitioned for higher ROEs 13 
because after the acquisition by Balfour Beatty, UPPCO was smaller and greater risk than 14 
when it was a subsidiary of Integrys.3  15 
 16 
Q. Does  Witness  Addonizio recognize  that the Commission has ongoing  authority over 17 
Minnesota Power ’s ROE ?  18 
A. Yes. Witness  Addonizio recognizes that the methods the Commission has historically 19 
relied on to estimate the COE  for ratemaking purpose s can  continue to be used to mitigate 20 
the risk that ratepayers bear higher costs as a result o f the Acquisition .4 Witness Addonizio 21 
and I agree that the Commission’s existing methodologies to estimate the COE  for a 22 
regulated utility will continue to be useful to establish appropriate ROE to authorize for 23 
Minnesota Power after the Acquisition. The Acquisition will not impede the use of that 24 
process for Minnesota Power, nor will it circumvent the Commission’s authority in setting 25 
the authorized ROE for Minnesota Power.  26

2 SIERRA Ex. __ (CL) at 15 (“Lane Direct”).

Q. How does Witness Addonizio think that the Acquisition could increase rates of 2 
return ? 3 
A. Witness Addonizio  suggests that there is potential to increase returns through “financial 4 
engineering , governance engineering and operational engineering ” as described in the 5 
offered  textbook  in support for th ese theoretical concept s5 Witness  Addonizio asserted that 6 
financial engineering , as discussed in a referenced textbook, would call for the increased 7 
use of debt to impose discipline on a company to “prevent management from engaging in 8 
wasteful, value -destroying activities .” However, Witness Addonizio  acknowledges that 9 
this purpose for debt financing does not apply to regulated utilities as strongly as it does to 10 
unregulated  firms.6  11 
 12 
Q. Is Witness  Addonizio correct that the return requirements are based on the investor 13 
and not the investment?  14 
A.  No. While Witness Addonizio appears to suggest that the ROE for Minnesota Power could 15 
be different based on who invests in the utility, the COE  that is to be expected from 16 
Minnesota Power should be based on the risk of investment in Minnesota Power . The 17 
theoretical concepts that Witness  Addonizio discusses are based on  returns that are 18 
different  from the regulated rate of return for a utility’s rates . The regulated rate of return 19 
used to establish rates will be determined by the Commission, and Witness  Addonizio 20 
seems to agree that the Acquisition will not have any impact on the Commission’s ability 21 
to do so.7  22 
 23 
The investment return that the Partners hope to achieve is a different concept and will be 24 
based on many additional factors other than  the regulated rate of return.  The investment  25 
return for the Partners  may be higher than the return on Minnesota Power  based on a 26

Bulkley Rebuttal  number of factors . However, many of those factors, including financing decisions , will not 1 
affect the ROE  or rate of return for Minnesota Power.  2 
 3 
Regulatory commissions focus on the utility rather than the utility’s owners in setting the 4 
return on equity.  Similarly, (and wholly separate from this Acquisition), the immediate 5 
investor in many regulated utilities within a holding company structure is the holding 6 
company , rather than the investors in the public market in which the holding company 7 
seeks equity. In all of those circumstances, regulatory commissions, including this 8 
Commission , do not set an authorized rate of return based on holding company 9 
requirements for its utilities; rather, under Hope  and Bluefield , commissions  base the 10 
authorized return for the operating utilities owned by holding companies on the estimated 11 
COE  investments in utilities of similar risks.  The same is true for private investors, who 12 
are entitled to returns based on the risk of the company in which they are investing.  Indeed, 13 
where an investor is willing to provide capital even during market downturns  and thereby 14 
absorb  the risk the utility would face in the public markets, the investor should be 15 
compensated commensurate with the level of the utility’s (not the investor’s) risk.  16 
 17 
Q. What is Witness  Addonizio’s main concern related to the weighted average cost of 18 
capital?  19 
A.  Witness  Addonizio explains that his primary concern is that debt at the Alloy Parent could 20 
increase the cost of borrowing for Minnesota Power, which would increase  the overall 21 
weighted average cost of capital (“ WACC ”).8 22 
 23

Bulkley Rebuttal  Q. Please summarize Witness Addonizio’s concerns regarding the potential for an 1 
increase in the cost of debt for Minnesota Power as a result of the financing decisions 2 
of the Alloy Parent.  3 
A. While  Witness  Addonizio  recognizes  the differences between rate-regulated utilities and 4 
unregulated entities  and explains  the control of the regulator in setting rates for regulated 5 
utilities . He suggests , however,  that there is possibility that debt financing at the Alloy 6 
Parent could result in a downgrade for A LLETE  and Minnesota Power, as a result of the 7 
debt held at the parent company . Witness Addonizio asserts that this debt  could cause credit 8 
rating agencies to change the outlook on ALLETE and Minnesota Power. Witness 9 
Addonizio suggests that if there were a downgrade of ALLETE or Minnesota Power that 10 
resulted from the upstream Alloy Parent debt , the cost of debt could increase for 11 
customers.9  12 
 13 
Q. Do you agree with Witness Addonizio’s concern that the cost of debt for ALLETE 14 
and Minnesota Power could increase as a result of the financing decisions at Alloy 15 
Parent ? 16 
A. No. Witness  Addonizio has not disputed the position that the Commission will continue to 17 
regulate the Minnesota Power ’s capital structure , thereby determining the amount of debt 18 
that can be used to finance the operations of Minnesota Power  and the cost of that debt .10 19 
Further, Witness  Addonizio recognizes that the Commission has established 20 
methodologies for setting the authorized ROE that are reasonable to be used going forward 21 
following the Acquisition.11 To the extent there are any concerns regarding the cost of debt 22 
for Minnesota Power in the future, the costs that are included in rates will be determined 23 
by the Commission.  Therefore, to the extent the Commission determines , in any rate 24 
proceeding, that the cost proposed by Minnesota Power  for recovery in rates  are not just or 25 
 
9 Addonizio Direct at 69 -70.  
10 Addonizio  Direct  at 64.  
11 Addonizio Direct at 53.

Bulkley Rebuttal  reasonable, it will continue to be within the Commission’s authority to make prudent 1 
adjustments to those costs.  2 
 3 
Q. Has Witness  Addonizio provided any evidence that the Partners intend to engage in 4 
financing that will increase WACC or otherwise increase overall cost to customers ?  5 
A. No. Witness  Addonizio has recognized that the Partners have agreed that they do not expect 6 
to engage in financial , governance or operational engineering . Nor has Witness Addonizio 7 
pointed to any evidence of practices that would in fact increase costs to customers . Witness 8 
Addonizio  has just raised generalized concerns without tying them to the Partners or the 9 
Acquisition.  10 
 11 
Nevertheless , to the extent that there is any increase in the WACC as a result of increased 12 
borrowing costs, the Partners have committed that, for three years following the 13 
transaction, if the cost of debt increases above current levels, Minnesota Power customers 14 
will be held harmless unless the utility demonstrates that the increase was not caused by 15 
the Acquisition. This commitment eliminates the possibility of any negative impacts to 16 
customers related to the cost of debt.  17 
 18 
Q. What is your response to Witness  Addonizio’s claims that the Partners have disclose d 19 
an expectation to earn a return on Alloy that is higher than the average return on an 20 
investment in a publicly -traded utility?  21 
A. Witness  Addonizio ’s comparison is flawed and unreliable  for several  reasons. First, a 22 
return on Alloy is not specific or limited to utility operations, but rather to the overall 23 
operations of ALLETE , including its nonregulated businesses. Second, Witness Addonizio  24 
is comparing  the historical  return on utility distribution company assets to the projected 25 
return on the portfolio of assets included in all of  ALLETE that is being valued by the 26 
Partners . Third, the Partners’ anticipated return on investment includes the anticipated  27 
increase in valuation of ALLETE that will result from transmission and generation 28 
investment necessary for successful implementation of the clean energy transition, and 29

In short, Witness Addonizio’s comparison is ess entially apples and oranges.  2 
 3

Power customers as a result of the transaction.  20 
 21

Q.  Please summarize Witness  Lane’s testimony suggesting that capital costs  will increase 6 
as a result  of the Acquisition.  7 
A. Witness  Lane  claims that there is theoretical and empirical evidence that suggests that if 8 
the Acquisition is completed, the Partners would put pressure on ALLETE and Minnesota 9 
Power to increase returns. From a theoretical perspective, Witness  Lane suggest s that since 10 
GIP and CPP Investments could invest in ALLETE today  through  the public equity market, 11 
there must be an expectation that they can earn a greater return on investment than the 12 
return they could earn purchasing stock. Witness  Lane suggests that the empirical support 13 
for this position is that private equity investments have better returns than the stock market, 14 
by a significant margin , concluding  that “Minnesota Power would be in a position where 15 
its equity holders would be demanding a higher average return than has been demanded by 16 
ALLETE shareholders  in public markets. ” Witness Lane  states that the Partners will 17 
attempt to achieve  these higher returns by  aggressively petitioning the Commission for a 18 
higher ROE.15 Further, Witness  Lane suggests that the Partners may push for greater capital 19 
investment rather than operating expense solutions to address system needs, which would 20 
be a higher -cost choice for customers.  21 
 22 
Q.  How do you respond to Witness  Lane’s theoretical position ? 23 
A. There are several flaws in Witness Lane’s theoretical position. First, Witness  Lane’s 24 
theoretical position fails to take into consideration the  fact that as owners of  ALLETE, the 25 
partners  have the ability to implement  strategies that meet the clean energy transition goals  26 
of Minnesota Power as well as other regulated and non -regulated investments that 27

Bulkley Rebuttal  ALLETE will need to make in the fu ture, which cannot be implemented as stock market 1 
investors.  Accomplishing this transition will substantially increase the value of ALLETE  2 
but also will be consistent with the Partners’ investment focus as communicated to their 3 
investors, helping them achieve the goals described in the Direct Testimony of Partner  4 
Witness es Alley and  Bram.  5 
 6 
Second, as discussed in my response to Witness  Addonizio, the investment opportunity in 7 
ALLETE  includes key longer -term investment  objectives rather than short -term dividend 8 
requirements as a stock market investor.  Finally, returns from  unregulated operations of 9 
ALLETE will not increase the cost of capital for Minnesota Power.  10 
 11 
Q. Is Witness  Lane correct that the increase in capital investment in Minnesota Power 12 
will increase the rate of return  to the Partners ?  13 
A.  No. The  Commission provides Minnesota Power a reasonable opportunity to earn an 14 
authorized ROE  on rate base assets . That ROE is applied to every dollar of equity 15 
investment  in such assets . While the total return in dollars may increase as investment 16 
increases, the rate of  return to each dollar of investment does not increase.  Further, the level 17 
of regulated investment on which returns can be earned depends on the Commission’s 18 
approval of Minnesota Power’s  investments.  Therefore, it is not reasonable to suggest that 19 
growth in rate base will result in higher  rates of  return to the Partners  or unreasonable levels 20 
of investment .  21 
 22 
Q. What is your response to Witness  Lane’s sug gestion that there is empirical evidence 23 
that private equity ownership will cause  utilities to aggressively petition the 24 
Commission for a higher ROE?  25 
A. Witness  Lane has provided no empirical evidence that demonstrates that utilities routinely 26 
seek higher ROEs following private equity acquisitions, whether  specifically related to the 27

Bulkley Rebuttal  acquisition or the expectation of higher returns from new owners.16 Witness  Lane cites t wo 1 
articles that discuss the performance of private equity as compared with the broader 2 
market ,17 but these studies do not offer any analysis of the authorized ROEs of regulated 3 
utilities  prior to or following an acquisition by a private equity firm .18 Witness  Lane makes 4 
a weak attempt to link these performance returns to the earned returns for utility 5 
investments over a five-year period as reported by Morningstar and suggests that because 6 
the five -year return on utilities was lower than private equity, there is “empirical evidence” 7 
to demonstrate that ROE requests will increase. Witness  Lane’s logic is flawed and the two 8 
reports do not offer any analysis of authorized returns.  As a result,  the attempt to link these 9 
two reports cannot be construed as  “empirical evidence” that ROE requests will increase  10 
as a result of the Acquisition .   11 
 12 
Q. Do customers have another protection against higher ROEs that Witness Lane has 13 
ignored?  14 
A. Yes. As discussed previously, Minnesota Power’s  ROE is regulated by the Commission. 15 
Witness  Addonizio and I agree that the Commission has existing  methodologies that have 16 
been  used to estimate the COE  that inform the Commission’s decision s as to the 17 
appropriate ROE to authorize to utilities that they regulate. The A cquisition does not 18 
impede that process , nor does it circumvent the Commission’s authority in setting the 19 
authorized ROE. Witness Lane gave no weight to this strong and ongoing protection from 20 
the Commission.   21 
 22
