Bulkley Rebuttal  Q. Does the Commission  also have the ability to assess a utility’s decisions to invest in or 1 
purchase energy needs  as it applies to potential rate base  additions and the associated 2 
returns on equity ?  3 
A.  Yes. Witness  Lane’s concern about the use of capital investment versus operating expenses 4 
is also addressed through Commission regulation  both before a generation or transmission  5 
investment is made, and after the investment is made . In addition to the Commission’s role 6 
in IRPs, any  capital investment placed into service is subject to regulatory review and the 7 
scrutiny of the Commission and the intervenors in rate proceedings. Therefore, to the extent 8 
that capital investments were made when operating expenses would have sufficed, 9 
intervenors have an opportunity to review these investments and provide opinions for the 10 
Commission’s review and consideration. Ultimately, the Commission determines the need 11 
for generation and transmission investments and prudence with respect to capital 12 
investments. The threat of disallowance of investment  is real and creates the appropriate 13 
incentive to ensure that utilities make sound investment decisions for customers.  14 
 15 
Q.  Please summarize Witness  Jester’s position with respect to the increased capital costs 16 
resulting from the acquisition of UPPCO.  17 
A.  Witness  Jester reviewed two transactions related to UPPCO, 1) the sale of UPPCO by 18 
Integr ys to Balfour Beatty (Michigan Public Utilities Case No. U -17564) and 2) Balfour 19 
Beatty’s sale of UPPCO to Axium UP Holdings LLC. (Michigan Public Utilities Case No. 20 
U-20995). Witness  Jester suggested that after the initial sale from Integr ys to Balfour 21 
Beatty, in UPPCO ’s next rate proceeding “UPPCO requested a large increase in its return 22 
on common equity, partly on the basis that it was now a small, higher -risk, utility than 23 
when it was a wholly owned subsidiary of Integrys.”19 24 
 25 
 
19 Jester Direct at 8.

Bulkley Rebuttal  Q. Is Witness  Jester’s characterization of UPPCO’s ROE request in Case No. U -17654 1 
accurate?  2 
A. No. Witness  Jester implies  that UPPCO was suggesting that its size had changed since the 3 
transfer of ownership from Integrys to a smaller company. In order to determine if Witness  4 
Jester ’s statement had any merit, I reviewed the testimony of the cost of capital witnesses 5 
who filed testimony in UPPCO’s rate proceedings from 2011 through 202 2. These cases 6 
span the period prior to the Balfour Betty acquisition in August 2014 and following the 7 
Axium UP Holdings LLC acquisition  in June 2021. This evidence demonstrates that 8 
Witness Jester does not correctly characterize UPPCO’s testimony over a continuum of 9 
rate proceedings from 2011 through 2020. As shown in  below, in each of these proceedings  10 
before and after the acquisition s, the cost of capital witness identified the small size of 11 
UPPCO  as a factor in the ROE request . Further,  the ROE requests were largely in the same 12 
range before and after the acquisitions and the authorized ROE stayed the same after the 13 
last acquisition.  14

Bulkley Rebuttal  Q. What conclusion does this data support?  1 
A.  It is clear from the data provided that UPPCO  had requested a consistent ROE regardless 2 
of the transactions that were occurring, until the 2018 time-period, when UPPCO’s  request 3 
was reduced by 25 basis points. Therefore, Witness  Jester’s view that the 2014 acquisition 4 
of UPPCO by Balfour Betty  resulted in an increase in the requested ROE due to a change 5 
in the size of Balfour Betty  is simply incorrect.  6 
 7 
Q. Was there a change in the methodologies used to estimate the COE  for UPPCO as a 8 
result of the transactions?  9 
A.  No. Each of the cost of capital witnesses relied on a proxy group of companies it believed 10 
to be  reasonably risk -comparable to UPPCO  and each witness developed several COE  11 
estimation models  using the  selected proxy group companies. This is consistent with the 12 
general methodology that I outlined in my direct testimony as the process that  has remained 13 
the long -standing process for setting ROEs in Minnesota and would continue to be 14 
appropriate for setting the ROE for Minnesota Power following the Acquisition.  15 
 16 
 FINANCING STRUCTURE IS MANAGED THROUGH REGULATION  17 
Q. Please summarize the view of the intervenors that “financial engineering” could be 18 
used in a way that increases  Minnes ota Power’s cost of capital ? 19 
A. Witness  Addonizio  speculates that the private equity investors could adjust Alloy ’s capital 20 
structure by replacing equity with debt , and that increment al increases in the percentage of 21 
debt will increase the leverage and financial risk  of Allo y, which  could  increase the cost of 22 
capital for both ALLETE and Minnesota Power. For example, Witness  Addonizio explains 23 
that Alloy  only own s ALLETE  and therefore would rely on its debt obligations  to be paid 24 
by the cash flows of ALLETE and as a result primarily the cash flows of Minnesota Power.  25 
As a result, Witness Addonizio  argues  that incremental debt issue d by Alloy could  result 26 
in financial pressure, and Alloy theoretically could extract additional cash from Minnesota 27 
Power by forgoing capital expenditures, increas ing the debt ratio , and reducing 28

14 
OAH Docket No.: 25 -2500 -40339  
MPUC Docket No.  E015/PA -24-198 
Bulkley Rebuttal  maintenance budgets.25 Witness Addonizio is concerned that this could increase the risk of  1 
Minnesota Power and  the Minnesota Power’s  cost of both debt and equity.   2 
 3 
    Similarly, OAG witness  Leben s argues that all private equity firms will increase  leverage 4 
in order to increase returns to equity investors.26 According to Witness Lebens, this would 5 
be achieved by Alloy issuing debt and increasing its leverage and using the debt to invest 6 
in Minnesota Power as equity . Like Witness  Addonizio, Witness  Lebens also notes that 7 
increased leveraged can weaken credit metrics and a company’s credit rating.27  8 
     9 
Q. Is the possibility of  “financial engineering” as referenced by Witness Addonizio 10 
higher with private equity ownership  than with publicly traded companies?  11 
A. No. Witness  Addonizio contends that in order to create additional value, private equity 12 
investors will replace equity with debt because the interest expense on debt is tax 13 
deductible which creates tax savings and increases value to equity holders.28 However, this 14 
same tax advantage is also available to publicly traded companies who can fund 15 
investments and acquisitions with debt and deduct the interest payments. Therefore, 16 
Witness  Addonizio’s concern is not unique to ownership  private equity firms . 17 
 18 
Q. Does Witness  Addonizio acknowledge that the Partners  have been clear  they will not 19 
engage in inappropriate “financial engineering”?  20 
A. Yes. Witness  Addonizio states that the Partners noted that : 1) the Acquisition will be 21 
funded with $300 million in debt  or 8 percent, a much lower percentage than many other 22

Q. How do regulators , including the Commission,  protect utilities against inappropriate 2 
financial engineering.?  3 
A. Regulatory commissions establish the capital structure and the return on the components 4 
of capital used to finance the utility  in the context of a rate proceeding. To the extent that 5 
some form of financial engineering is implemented within the utility  between rate 6 
proceedings, that resulted in excessive returns  to a utility, the utility  can be required to file 7 
a rate proceeding at which time all costs can be reevaluated  and reset. The Commission has 8 
the authority to establish a capital structure that is reasonable and appropriate  in any rate 9 
proceeding  and financial decisions of upstream entities do not change their  authority .  10 
  11

regulate Minnesota Power’s  capital structure and cost of capital?  13 
A. Yes. In fact, Witness  Addonizio notes that the Partners acknowledged that Minnesota 14 
Power’s capital structure will still be regulated by the Commission  and therefore, the 15 
Partners would be limited in  any financial engineering at Minnesota Power.30 Further, 16 
Witness  Addonizio recognizes the solution to any concerns about effects  on the cost of 17 
debt of Minnesota Power , noting  that if the Commission  in a rate proceeding  were to 18 
determine that Minnesota Power‘s  cost of debt was “unreasonably high” due to the 19 
Acquisition, the Commi ssion could use a “representative interest rate” for the debt 20 
issuances affected by the Acquisition that w as based on debt issuance s for utilities with 21 
high credit ratings . Finally, while Witness  Addonizio contends that Minnesota Power’s  22 
COE  could increase as a result of the Acquisition , he conclude s that the COE  23 
metho dologies historically relied on by the Commission should continue to be used post - 24 
acquisition to set the ROE for Minnesota Power . As a result, while Witness  Addonizio 25 
discussed at length  the risk of “ financial engineering ” on Minnesota Power’s  capital 26

Commission’s ongoing regulation of Minnesota Power.  2 
 3 
Q. Is Witness  Leben s correct that increasing the amount of debt to fund an investment 4 
will yield a higher return?  5 
A. No. Witness  Lebens testimony could be understood to suggest  that the return on investment 6 
in Minnesota Power should be based on the source of f unds, as opposed to the risk of the 7 
investment . Such a position  would be illogical  and violate well -recognized financial 8 
principles . For example, in Principles of Corporate Finance, Brealey, Myers and Allen 9 
note that the return should be based on the risk of the investment : 10 
In principle, each project should be evaluated at its own opportunity 11 
cost of capital; the true cost of capital depends on the use to which the 12 
capital is put. If we wish to estimate the cost of capital for a particular 13 
project, it is project risk that counts .31 14 
 15 
Q. Does Witness Lebens analogy based on the purchase of a home apply to the financing 16 
of a utility, such as Minnesota Power?   17 
A. No. The flaw  in Witness  Lebens ’ home purchase  analogy to the financing of a business  is 18 
the failure to recognize that the use of debt by an investor to fund an equity investment in 19 
a business does not affect the risk of the equity investment in the business , which is the 20 
basis for determining a utility’s regulated return . Therefore, Witness Lebens’ 21 
homeownership example does not provide a clear illustration of how the risks to the 22 
investor  increase when an investor uses debt to provide equity funding into a utility capital 23 
structure.  Witness Lebens’ analogy appears to be trying to explain how the Partners would 24 
achieve a higher return on their investment in ALLETE implicating a higher return on 25 
equity for Minnesota Power. For the same reasons as Witness Addonizio’s similar 26 
argument addressed above, such a comparison between returns on ALLETE and Minnesota 27 
Power’s utility return on equity is apples and oranges  28 
 
31 Richard A. Brealey, Stewart C. Myers, Franklin Allen, Principles of Corporate Finance, McGraw -Hill Irwin, 8th 
Ed., 2006, at 234.

 II. REBUTTAL OF WITNESS  ADDONIZIO’S TESTIMONY  1 
Q.  What potential financial harms to Minnesota Power does Witness  Addonizio assert 2 
will result from the Acquisition  of ALLETE by the Partners?  3 
A.  Witness  Addonizio assert s that : (1) the Partners may be unwilling to provide equity 4 
capital or they may have  better investment opportunities elsewhere ;8 (2) raising equit y 5 
at ALLETE through the issuance of preferred equity  is not a satisfactory back -up plan , 6 
since he does not view  preferred stock as equity ;9 and (3) the utility could be burdened 7 
by excessive debt leverage due to the debt of a parent company, or the utility ’s credit 8 
ratings  could be downgraded due to distress of its corporate parent or an affiliate .10  9

Q.  How do you respond to Witness  Addonizio regarding the possibility that the 11 
Partners  may be unwilling  to provide equity to Minnesota  Power  or that the equity 12

equity in other investments ?  14 
A.  There will be no reason for the Partners to withhold equity funds from Minnesota Power 15 
if the returns available on the investment are competitive with the returns for similarly 16 
situated companies. The motivation for any investor to invest in the equity of a rate - 17 
regulated public utility is reliance upon the regulatory compact  – that is, confidence that 18 
the regulatory authority will allow the utility the opportunity to earn returns consistent 19 
with those earned by companies of comparable risk. In fact, t his is the underlying 20 
premise for investment in the equity of any investor -owned utility, whether by public or 21 
private equity investors. This concept is enshrined in Hope Natural Gas  and Bluefield .   22 
 23 
In addition, the Partners have proposed  an explicit  commit ment  that Alloy Parent will 24 
invest sufficient equity in ALLETE  to allow the Company to fulfill Minnesota Power ’s 25 
capital plan for the first five years after closing ; this is a commitment that is not available 26 
from public market investors.  27

 Q.  Witness  Addonizio asserts  that preferred stock is not equity  and has bond -like 1 
interest payments l ike debt . What is your response?  2 
A.  Witness  Addonizio is incorrect. Witness  Addonizio objects to the Partners’ statement 3 
that in the unlikely case that they were unable to provide equity capital, as a back -up 4 
plan ALLETE could  instead  issue preferred stock ; in his comments he  reveals that he is 5 
misinformed about  the nature  of preferred equity. Preferred stock is a form of equity 6 
and is not the same as debt.  Although preferred shares  bear a fixed coupon rate, the 7 
dividends on preferred shares are not owed  unless the board of directors declares the 8 
dividend.  If the issuer is stressed and short of cash , the board of directors  can suspend 9 
preferred dividend payments.  Typically , if preferred dividends are omitted, no common 10 
dividends can be declared and paid.  If the omission of preferred dividend payments 11 
continues for a specified number of years, the preferred shareholders have the right to 12 
appoint a certain number of directors.   13 
 14 
These features are not characteristics of debt, and that is why preferred stock appears on 15 
the balance sheet as an equity and not as a liability.  In brief, preferred shares are a form 16 
of equity.  That being said, it is extremely  likely that the Partners will be fully capable 17 
of providing the Company with the needed equity, so the issuance of preferred shares is 18 
only relevant as a back -up option.  19 
 20

Q. How did you view capital plans when you were an investment analyst at UBS?  2 
A. I regularly reviewed utility -provided capital plans and evaluated them.  My core stock 3 
valuation models were based on five -year financial models. I built a five -year financial 4 
model of each covered company that included a projection of five -year capital 5 
expenditures. I found industry financial planners to be highly professional and credible  6 
in developing capital plans that were a result of a rigorous internal review process with 7 
regulated and unregulated divisions competing for capital on a risk -adjusted basis . I 8 
occasionally  found it desirable  to tweak the timing and amount of capex provided by 9 
utility management and sometimes needed to create my own capex forecasts . For 10 
example,  some companies would disclose a three or four -year capital plan and my 11 
valuation model required five -years, so I would create the remaining years myself.  12 
However, I never observed a capital plan that I concluded was speculative, inaccurate , 13 
or unworthy.  14 
 15 
Q. How did you view capital plans when you were Chairman of the Michigan Public 16 
Service Commission?  17 
A. As Chairman of the Michigan Public Service Commission, I regularly reviewed and 18 
evaluated capital plans provided by Michigan utilities.  I encouraged the MPSC staff to 19 
review multi -year capital plans rather than focus exclusively on test year capital in rate 20 
cases. We understood that it is typical for capital plans to get updated periodically, and 21 
that it is reasonable to observe timing shifts, changing amounts, and shifting priorities 22 
over time.  We realized that significant amounts of capital were needed to provide 23 
service to customers and that when a capex project was delayed, it represented an 24 
opportunity to move other  projects earlier . We learned much about our utilities by 25 
deliberately taking a deep dive into their capital plans and made better rate case and 26 
other decisions as a result. It would have been irresponsible to cavalierly dismiss the 27 
capital plans out -of-hand as speculative and inaccurate, and unworthy of our review.  28 
 29

Q. What does Witness  Addonizio indicate about power purchase agreements 16 
(“PPAs ”) and how they relate to the capital plan?  17 
A. Witness  Addonizio suggests that PPAs are an alternative that can substitute for investing 18 
capital in renewable energy projects.6 However, PPAs are not a free ride for a utility. 19 
To begin with, PPAs sometimes are not cost -effective for customers. Case -by-case 20 
analysis will reveal which PPAs are economical , and which are not . It has been the 21 
Commission’s practice to approve a mix of PPAs and utility -owned projects for 22 
Minnesota Power based on which will result in the most cost -effective set of resources 23 
for customers.   24 
 25 
Q. Why are  PPAs  not always  beneficial for customers?  26 
A. Even for cost -effective PPAs, there is a practical limit on how much PPA exposure a 27 
utility can bear. PPAs must be carefully planned and implemented judiciously because 28 
they are long-lived , off-balance sheet obligations that investors take into consideration 29

functionally, imputed debt. Therefore, while direct capital may not be invested , the 3 
Company’s balance sheet and credit metrics can be significantly impacted by PPAs  and 4 
relying too extensively on PPAs could increase financing costs for customers . This  5 
issue, plus the cost of relative possible energy sources in the form of either PPAs or 6 
utility -owned investments, are  why determining the right mix of PPA s and Company - 7 
owned infrastructure is a key financial issue for the Company and can only be 8

it is reasonable for planning purposes to assume that capital will be spent even with a 10 
mix of PPAs or other arrangements.   11

Q. As a former commissioner, how do you view the  size of this capital and equity need 2 
in relation to customer needs and affordability?  3 
A. While capital investment and customer rates are related, they are not  the same thing, do 4 
not translate 1:1, and each depends on a variety of factors. It is up to the Company  to 5 
ensure it can finance the investments it needs to make to meet its obligation to serve 6 
customers reliably, safely, economically,  and consistent with State requirements,  and 7 
up to  the Commission to approve projects and investments, as well as cost recovery and 8 
cost allocation, for customers  that align with that obligation. Both the Company’s 9 
investments and the Commission’s review of those investments are tied to a number of 10 
factors, including state policy requirements (here, first the Renewable Energy Standard 11 
and then the Carbon Free Standard) , system reliability and resilience needs, and other 12 
state goals and policies  that are enacted for customers and in the public interest as that 13 
is set forth by the state legislature and the Commission . Further, it would be backward 14 
to suggest the Company should not have access to the capital it determines it needs to 15 
meet customer needs – this both gets into the areas of expertise of the utility , and 16 
hindering the Company’s access to capital can have unintended consequences . 17 
Fundamentally, the Commission’s role is not to do that, but to ensure that costs for 18 
customers are ultimately just and reasonable.  19

Quackenbush  Rebuttal  and Schedule  Q. What do you mean market volatility is a key consideration when issuing public 1 
equity?  2 
A. In both regulated and unregulated firm s, the corporate Treasury Department bears the 3 
responsibility of managing equity and debt offerings. The Treasurer’s job is to sell debt 4 
and equity at advantageous times, debt at the lowest interest rate and equity at the 5 
highest share price. Obviously, no Treasurer knows with precision where interest rates 6 
or stock prices are headed in the future. Once the Treasurer identifies the strategic need 7 
to issue equity and the offering size based on need and what the market can digest, the 8 
final decision becomes tactical ly choosing the timing. If a company needs to go to the 9 
market frequently, it has less flexibility to choose that timing.   10 
 11 
Q. Does  lack of flexibility in the timing of debt issuances have a lasting impact?  12 
A. Yes. The lack of flexibility is a significant concern because t he impact of issuing debt 13 
at a higher interest rate is long -lasting  and will impact the embedded cost of debt for the 14 
life of the debt security, which may be as long as ten or thirty years.  For example, the 15 
monthly average of S&P -rated  “BBB ” rated utility bond yield during 2024 varied from 16 
a low of 5.43  percent  to a high of 6.12  percent , a range of 69 basis points. The yields 17 
were somewhat more volatile during 2023 with a low of 5.24  percent  and a high of 6.68  18 
percent , a range of 144 basis points. The impact on customers can be meaningful since  19 
a ten -basis point increase in the cost of debt as it relates to the Company’s 2023 rate 20 
case outcome translates to about $1.1 million of  Minnesota Power ’s revenue 21 
requirement  increase . 22

Q. Does lack of flexibility  in the timing of equity issuances have a lasting impact?  24 
A.  Yes. The impact of issuing equity at a low stock price is permanent. Having to issue a 25 
greater number of shares to raise a given block of equity at a low price is detrimental 26 
compared to the ability to issue a lower number of shares at a higher price  because of 27 
dilution , as will be demonstrated by an Otter Tail Corporation example that I will 28 
provide . Once the issuance occurs  and the fixed amount of cash is received , the net 29 
proceeds of the equity offering is permanently on the  equity side of the  balance sheet  at 30 
that fixed level.   31

Q. Why does it matter if a company has to issue a greater number of shares at a low 2 
price to raise equity capital?  3 
A. Existing equity investors care about the issuance share price because of dilution. 4 
Witness  Addonizio acknowledges in his Direct Testimony.12 The lower the sale price 5 
of new shares, the larger the dilutive impact to existing shareholders  because the shares 6 
they hold also will become less valuable . Dilution is negative for existing shareholders. 7 
When equity investors experience dilution, they perceive a higher risk of it happening 8 
again by the same issuer. This would be particularly true if the shareholders knew the 9 
issuer would need to go back to the market multiple times over the near term ; it could 10 
build in an expectation of future dilution . So, an issuer’s attempt to avoid dilution is 11 
more than just an unwillingness  as Witness  Addonizio argues , but an attempt to maintain 12 
access to future capital from public investors . Investors  and regulators  expect prudent 13 
Treasurers to avoid or at least minimize dilutive impacts and will react negatively 14 
otherwise.  15 
 16 
Q. Do utility customers benefit from avoiding dilution?  17 
A. Customers also benefit from avoiding share price dilution, too, because the cost of 18 
equity, which is ultimately recovered through utility rates that customers pay, is kept 19 
lower by minimizing shareholder risks.  In other words, if shareholders experience or 20 
expect dilution, they will see the stock as higher risk and demand a higher return, which 21 
directly feeds into customer rates. For example, the impact on customers can be 22 
meaningful since a ten -basis point increase in the cost of equity as it relates to the 23 
Company’s 2023 rate case outcome translates to about $1.8 million of  Minnesota Power 24 
revenue requirement increase.  25

For a conceptual  dilution example, assume that ALLETE identifies a need for $ 120 27 
million of equity capital. Assuming public market issuance costs of $ 5 million, then it 28 
would need to sell 2.0 million shares if the share price is $ 62.50  per share to net $ 120 29

Tail’s  stock price declin ed immediately and when Otter Tail closed the public equity 29

Q. Is Witness  Addonizio correct that disruption of ALLETE’s stock price is not “a 15 
significant concern” because the stock market is efficient?14 16 
A. No prudent Treasurer would ever  say “because the market is efficient in the long -run, I 17 
do not care about the stock price or specific day on which I issue equity.” While the 18 
macroeconomic concepts like long -run market efficiency that Witness  Addonizio relies 19 
on read well in a textbook, they do not always translate to practical or prudent corporate 20 
operations ; nor does the purported efficiency necessarily help keep costs down for 21 
customers . In reality , the Treasurer works with investment bankers and other advisors 22 
to choose the timing of an issuance for a day with minimal exogenous factors such as  23 
market disruptions, technical factors, negative market sentiment,  negative new s flows, 24 
and minimal other  issuances  competing for investors’ attention . Oftentimes, the right 25 
answer is to wait through market volatility, which is manageable  if the equity offering 26 
is non -serial, such as once every 3 -5 years. However, a serial issuer  such as ALLETE 27 
would be in the future  does not have the luxury of waiting for an optimal time to issue 28 
its block of equity. A serial issuer, acting on a stand -alone basis, must forge ahead with 29

approved , ties the hands of the Treasury Department  already subject to the constraints 4

Q. Is Witness  Addonizio  correct  that the risk of serial issuance is a problem for 11 
investors, but not for customers?  12 
A. No. Witness  Addonizio seems to suggest that the risk of serially issuing shares, reducing 13 
the stock price and diluting the value of existing shares, is a risk borne only by existing 14 
investors. But that is not the case, because of the potential impact  of increased dividend  15 
payment s resulting from a flawed issuance.  As an issuer’s stock price drops, more shares 16 
are required to be issued for the same  dollar amount of equi ty raised.  The more shares 17 
that are issued  without the benefit of  raising additional  equity , the higher the 18 
corresponding  dividend payment requirement (even i f the dividend rate is held flat) and 19 
the lower the company’s cash flow, which is a primary  measure of financial health . 20 
Lower cash flow is a primary driver  of increased risk and even more needed capital. 21 
Customers benefit from a financially healthy utility  and would be harmed by a continual 22 
downward spiral cr eated by issuances at lower stock prices.  The impact on customers 23 
would be even greater if a stand -alone company were unable to serially access sufficient 24 
capital.  25

A. In the public markets, equity investors expect to earn a return through both dividends 21 
and stock price appreciation. The dividend component of the return is extremely 22 
important for a utility investor. Public market utility investors value steady dividend 23 
payments that are paid quarterly and modestly increased annually. Breaking this pattern 24 
by skipping or reducing a dividend payment signals serious financial distress and 25 
violates a core tenant of why public investors invest in low -risk low -return utilities . 26 
Public investors respond in part by selling their shares, reducing share price and 27 
demanding a higher return on future issuances to compensate for the risk that they might 28 
not receive dividends as expected and desired.  29

IV. RESPONSE TO LPI WITNESS WALTERS  9 
Q. Does Witness  Walters appear to understand the sequence of events  leading to this 10 
proposed transaction ? 11 
A. No. Witness  Walters appears to be under the impression that the proposed transaction, 12 
rather than state policy goals, is driving ALLETE’s increased capital plan.32 Witness  13 
Walters has the cause and effect  exactly backwards. He fails to acknowledge that the 14 
proposed transaction is a result of expected future access to capital issues that challenge 15 
ALLETE as it seeks to fulfill state policy goals. This Commission will address build 16 
and spend issues as it reviews ALLETE’s capital plan in future IRP proceedings and 17 
cost recovery in future rate cases.  These are not issues that need to be resolved in this 18 
proceeding, which is focused on determining whether the Acquisition is consistent with 19 
the public interest.  20 
 21 
Q. What does Witness  Walters say about operational cost synergies ? 22 
A. Like Witness  Addonizio, Witness  Walters indicates that he looked for operational cost 23 
synergies  that have been used as justification for previous Commission -approved 24 
acquisitions in this proposed acquisition.33 However, operational cost synergies  are 25 
often found in strategic mergers, where one utility is acquiring another utility. They are 26 
not expected to be a driving force in financial mergers  like this Acquisition , where 27 
financial investors are acquiring a utility. So, it should not be surprising that access to 28 
capital issues are more important than strategic benefits in this proposed transaction.  29

Quackenbush  Rebuttal  and Schedule   1 
Q. Witness  Walters argues that most of ALLETE’s current investors are institutional 2 
investors who provide access to patient capital today. Do you agree with Witness  3 
Walters ’ characteriz ation  of these institutional investors?  4 
A. No, I do not. Witness  Walters claims that all institutional investors are long -term 5 
investors  providing patient capital .34 This is misleading because numerous institutional 6 
investors, such as hedge funds, pursue  short -term hedging strategies that can noticeably 7 
impact stock prices . Hedge funds are actively managed and often implement strategies 8 
that are short -term in nature  using complex trading and risk management techniques . 9 
Some strategies,  for example, are tied to quarterly earnings announcements. Large 10 
hedge fund tran sactions can significantly impact stock prices, thus causing unattractive 11 
periods of time for an equity issuer to issue a block of equity. For a serial issuer in public 12 
markets like ALLETE is on the path  to become, this is particularly problematic. Thus, 13 
his assertion that all institutional investors can be presumed to be long -term investors 14 
providing patient capital like the Partners is false.    15 
 16 
It is more accurate  to characterize institutional investors as a mix of long -term and short - 17 
term investors. Public markets consist of a mix of long -term and short -term investors, 18 
with long -term investors focused on long -term fundamentals like dividends and cash 19 
flows and short -term investors focused on technical factors and issues that can at times 20 
skew stock valuations away from long -term fundamental valuations. It is not possible 21 
to know ahead of any new issuance to raise capital whether long -term or short -term 22 
investors will participate in the new issuance. This is a good demonstration of why a 23 
public equity issuance must also consider tactical timing issues. Heavy short -term 24 
influences can be more readily handled by an infrequent public issuer but are more 25 
problematic for a serial issuer  like ALLETE will be . All these public market dynamic s 26 
become moot when patient long -term private equity investors are the owners.  In that 27 
way, t he existence of this observed short -term market behavior highlights the 28 
attractiveness of patient private equity to a serial issuer.   29 
 
34 Walters Direct at 34.

Quackenbush  Rebuttal  and Schedule    1 
Q. Does Witness  Walters accurately characterize typical investment decision making 2 
for long -term investors?  3 
A. No, Witness Walters does not.  In an attempt to characterize the Partners as something 4 
other than long -term investors, Witness  Walters characterizes holding periods of seven  5 
and ten years as selling “in the near future.”35 To the contrary, s even - and ten -year 6 
holding periods are not considered short holding periods. A Reuters study using New 7 
York Stock Exchange data show that the average holding period for U.S. shares was 5.5 8 
months in June 2020, down from 8.5 months at the end of 2019, which was down from 9 
14 months in 1999, a nd has been falling for decades.36 10 
 11 
Long -term investors are characterized as such because they intend to invest for the  long- 12 
term, but often sell sooner for various reasons . In my experience, both public and private 13 
long-term investors sometimes sell earlier than intended because their investment 14 
reached its price target earlier than expected  and the investor, who is  continually 15 
revising their valuation target , cannot justify  increas ing the target  valuation . On the 16 
other hand, an investor may sell the investment short of the original target  valuation 17 
because of a de cline  of the valuation target before the target price is reache d. In either 18 
event, circumstances can dictate that a long -term investor sells earlier than expected  19 
whether or not it is a public or private investor . Those circumstances (and the subsequent 20 
sale itself) are not necessarily problematic or a sign of issues with or negative 21 
developments at the utility . 22 
 23 
The fact that the Partners may, in the future, look to sell their investments in ALLETE 24 
is not actually a problem.  Any implication that such a sale by the Partners would be 25 
problematic also ignores the role the Commission plays in evaluating acquisitions and 26 
dispositions of the Company and ensuring they are consistent with the public interest. 27

Q. How do utility regulatory commissions make authorized ROE decisions in rate 4 
cases?  5 
A. The authorized ROE deliberation process is addressed on page 21 of  the NARUC Cost 6 
of Capital and Capital Markets Primer for Utility Regulators that I discussed in my 7 
Direct Testimony:  8 
When making ROE decisions, it is typical for regulatory commissions 9 
to be confronted with the perpetual challenge of having a record 10 
consisting of multiple ROE methodologies from multiple ROE 11 
witnesses representing multiple parties.  Amid the plethora of evidence 12 
before it, the regulatory commission is charged with considering and 13 
weighing all the evidence and determining a specific authorized ROE 14 
for use in developing tariffs.  The “weighing” part is challenging and 15 
can be different in each commissioner’s reasoning, but the task at hand 16 
for commissioners is to agree to an authorized ROE that is within the 17 
range or zone defined by the evidence.  18 
 19 
The Commission has been using this method for many years. The primer also highlights 20 
that case -specific circumstances  are important considerations. Because authorized ROE 21 
decisions are so heavily evidence -based, Witness  Ellis is also postulating that all 22 
financial expert witnesses that appear on behalf of utilities, Commission staffs, and 23 
Parties  before all utility regulatory commissions have also done ROE wrong in every 24 
rate case for decades. This proposition is preposterous and deserves no weight. Rather, 25 
it is Witness  Ellis’ peculiar opinion that is out -of-place.  26 
 27

on whether the Acquisition is consistent with the public interest . Witness  Ellis 31 
recommends to standardize and codify the process of calculating the ROR in rate 32 
cases.41 Standardizing and codifying any ROE formula would be a mistake. Further, 33

Before the Minnesota Public Utilities CommissionLaborers District Council of Minnesota and North Dakota(LIUNA Minnesota and North Dakota)In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition ofALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and GlobalInfrastructure PartnersOAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339MPUC Docket No, E015/PA-24-198Rebuttal Testimony of Erin BryantMarch 4, 2025LIUNA Bryant Rebuttal TestimonyQ: State your name, affiliation, and address.A: Erin Bryant, Laborers’ International Union of North America (“LIUNA”), 905 16thStreet NW, Washington, D.C. 20006.Q: Please summarize your testimony.A: The purpose of my testimony is to respond to direct testimony filed by theDepartment of Commerce and the Large Power Intervenors concerning how the proposedtransaction would likely affect governance, access to capital, and procurement of goods andservices by Minnesota Power. I am responding to the testimony of Department of Commercewitnesses Craig Addonizio and Stephanie Vavro, and Large Power Intervenor witnessChristopher Walters. Specifically, I will unpack flawed assumptions about the nature andoperation of private equity fund investment that underlie many critiques of the transaction;explain how private equity funds manage potential conflict of interests and other riskshighlighted by intervenors; and describe why the transaction is likely to provide public benefitsin the form of more dependable financing than ALLETE could secure going as a stand-aloneentity given the utility’s demonstrated capital needs.Q: Do you agree with Mr. Addonizio that Applicants have failed to demonstrate thatALLETE will struggle to raise the capital necessary for Minnesota Power to operatesuccessfully and meet regulatory obligations if the transaction is not approved?1LIUNA Bryant Rebuttal TestimonyA: I disagree with Mr. Addonizio’s assertion that Minnesota Power will not have greaterdifficulty meeting capital requirements if the transaction is not approved. Mr. Addonizio suggeststhat Minnesota Power’s past success is evidence that the utility’s needs can be met under thecurrent ownership structure.1 Mr. Addonizion’s analysis, however, fails to grapple with the scaleof near-term capital requirements which exceed ALLETE’s current market valuation by a largefactor and have no precedent in the company’s history.According to S&P Global news reports, Wall Street analysts note that financing theenergy transition for utilities with coal exposure has been a driver of utility merger andacquisitions over the past five years2. They note anticipated pace of capital expenditures toreplace the coal exposure has been a predictor of mergers, even if the company were not exposedto high levels of risk associated with reliance on a small number of large industrial customerswhich makes Minnesota Power fairly unique among regulated utilities. Taken together, thesefactors make it likely that traditional financing would be insufficient to execute ALLETE’scapital spending plans in a cost-effective manner.These trends also point toward the potential for ALLETE to become a target for anacquisition or merger with a larger utility that could negatively impact Minnesota Power’scustomers, communities and workers. The risks of public ownership include the possibility thatALLETE would be targeted by so-called “activist” investors that seek to force sales, mergers orcorporate reforms that maximize their returns at the expense of other stakeholders For example,2 S&P Global. Dan Lowrey and Darren Sweeney, “Allete Targeted Financial Buyers From Start of SalesProcess.” S&P Capital IQ, August 20, 2024. Accessed March 3, 2025https://www.capitaliq.spglobal.com/apisv3/spg-webplatform-core/news/article?ID=82740847&KPLT=2&redirected=1.1 Addonizio, Direct Testimony. OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339 & MPUC Docket No, E015/PA-24-198,February 4, 2025, 40, 45.2LIUNA Bryant Rebuttal Testimonyactivist hedge funds such as Icahn Capital, Corvex Capital, and Elliot have all targeted publiclytraded utility companies and have impacted stock price through their activism3.Q: How would you expect institutional investors to evaluate efforts by ALLETE tomeet projected capital needs as a stand-alone company through serial equity and debtissuance?A: Based on my experience working with private-sector and public-sector pension fundtrustees, investment advisors and fund managers, I would expect investors to be wary ofsignificant new ALLETE equity and debt offerings based on the aggressive growth factor andMinnesota Power’s exposure to risk associated with reliance on a handful of large, trade-exposedcustomers – both of which can be investment red flags. Any given equities manager working onbehalf of a pension fund may invest a small portion of their total assets in small, rapidly-growingcompanies with higher risk profiles, but they expect higher returns in compensation and oftenplace those investments alongside larger stakes of other, more attractive and less risky publiclytraded companies.Q: Why would pension funds generally be willing to invest equity in the growth ofALLETE as a privately-held portfolio company?3 The Columbus Dispatch. Mark Williams, 'AEP Targets Job Reductions Through Voluntary SeveranceProgram,' The Columbus Dispatch, April 27, 2024. Accessed March 3, 2025.https://www.dispatch.com/story/business/2024/04/27/aep-targets-job-reductions-through-voluntary-severance-program/73453338007/.Engineering News-Record. Richard Korman, 'Southwest Gas Sells Part of Contracting Unit Centuri inIPO,' Engineering News-Record, June 3, 2024. Accessed March 3, 2024.https://www.enr.com/articles/58756-southwest-gas-sells-part-of-contracting-unit-centuri-in-ipo.3LIUNA Bryant Rebuttal TestimonyA: Investments in public equities are subject to the whims of the market, which aredescribed accurately in the direct testimony of Mr. Quackenbush.4 Mr. Addonizio discounts Mr.Quackenbush’s testimony by citing a popular corporate finance textbook which finds that stockmarkets are fundamentally efficient and that stock prices are tied to long-term equity valuations.This is not consistent, however, with the experience of many LIUNA pension funds andinvestment advisors who have seen the volatility inherent in the publicly-traded ownershipstructure impact the utility sector as well.We observe these inefficiencies most often in industries where LIUNA has “boots on theground” through the participation of members and partner contractors in construction andmaintenance work (e.g. energy, real estate) which allows us to leverage industry-specificexpertise and intelligence. We hear similar accounts of market misunderstandings andinefficiencies, however, from colleagues whose unions represent workers and have expertise inother sectors (e.g. health care, hospitality), which suggests to us that these inefficiencies are afeature of public equity ownership and not unique to industries where construction plays asignificant role..LIUNA has worked closely through the Council of Institutional Investors and in otherforums to promote corporate governance reforms that are intended to address existinginefficiencies and misalignments between the interests of management, shareholders of varioustypes and sizes, company employees, and other stakeholders in publicly-traded companies. Yeteven companies that have adopted best practices with respect to governance and executivecompensation do not automatically provide better alignment of interests compared to privatelyheld companies. What protections are in place to discourage such conflicts of interest?A. When LIUNA pension funds allocate capital to an investment manager, they are operatingunder the ERISA Fiduciary Duty standards. As the U.S. Department of Labor notes, “Theprimary responsibility of fiduciaries is to run the plan solely in the interest of participants andbeneficiaries and for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits and paying plan expenses.Fiduciaries must act prudently and must diversify the plan's investments in order to minimize therisk of large losses. In addition, they must follow the terms of plan documents to the extent thatthe plan terms are consistent with ERISA. They also must avoid conflicts of interest. In other8LIUNA Bryant Rebuttal Testimonywords, they may not engage in transactions on behalf of the plan that benefit parties related tothe plan, such as other fiduciaries, services providers or the plan sponsor.9”Q. Why does fiduciary duty matter in a transaction like this?A. Fiduciary duty does not end at the pension fund’s board of trustees. It extends to theinvestment consultants who make recommendations and take on the discretion of recommendingreputable, ethical investment managers. If BlackRock, GIP, CPP, or their fund managers werecaught trying to enrich the firms, their managers, or investors in other managed funds on thebacks of investors in a given fund, the result could be catastrophic for future fundraising, and thecompanies and individuals would be exposed to legal consequences for breach of contract not tomention any potential criminal penalties. Most investors in private equity funds are known as limited partners when they hire aninvestment manager.
